However, for those in the southeast with internal heat and weak blood and qi, though temporary relief may be achieved, it will only lead to a weaker and drier spleen. Future users of this formula must understand that in the northwest, the focus should be on unblocking, whereas in the southeast, it should focus on moistening and relieving dryness. One must be careful not to be rigid in their approach.

    Regarding the prohibitions related to opening the bowels, I have observed that ancient formulas for relieving constipation all utilize downward-moving herbal preparations. This is because if lung qi does not descend, the bowels are reluctant to move, thus ingredients like apricot kernel, bitter orange, agarwood, and myrobalan are employed. Furthermore, for the elderly, the weak, or those with wind conditions who lack fluids and are constipated, herbs that provide lubrication are necessary, such as sesame, hemp seeds, and donkey-hide gelatin. If one rashly uses harsh purgative drugs to forcefully expel, the fluids will be depleted, and qi and blood will be consumed, leading to temporary relief but resulting in future constipation and the onset of other illnesses.

    In the past, Wang Shaofu suffered from this illness, and there were others who treated him with harsh medicines, ultimately resulting in his lung atrophy, coughing up blood and pus, which eventually led to his death from obstruction.[33p]

    　　　　　小便不禁

    　　小便不禁者，属热属虚。热者，五苓散加解毒。虚者，五苓加四物。　　小便不禁，有虚热、虚寒之分。内虚寒自汗者，秘元丹、三因韭子丸。　　内虚湿热者，六味丸或八味丸加杜仲、骨脂、五味。老人宜八味丸减泽泻为妙。　　因看卢家《医镜》，见此一药味数分两同，惟丹砂用伏火者，及治病有差，所治者小便数而不禁，怔仲多忘，魇梦不已不同耳。见其不同，审而详之，乃得此治法不瘥。且泛论之：经言肾主大便，肝主小便淋溲。《难经》云：小肠为赤肠。是面赤色及便溺色赤，皆出心与小肠，南方赤色显于外也。经言：下焦如渎者，正谓大小便也。大便为阴，为有形气化，乃下焦之下者也。谓肾主大便，不言大肠者，明子行父道，为肾脏病。小便为阳，为无形气化，乃下焦之高者也。谓肝主小便淋溲，亦是子行父道为腑病。凡诸无形气化者，皆腑病所主。[34p]

    Incontinence of Urination

    Incontinence of urination is associated with heat or weakness. For heat, apply Wuling San with detoxifying ingredients. For weakness, use Wuling with Siwu. Incontinence can be differentiated into weakness with heat or weakness with cold. For those with internal cold and spontaneous sweating, use Miyuan Dan or Sanyin Jiuzi Wan. For those with internal damp-heat, use Liu Wei Wan or Ba Wei Wan with Du Zhong, Gu Zhi, and Wu Wei. The elderly should ideally reduce Ze Xie in Ba Wei Wan.

    In reviewing Lu's "Mirror of Medicine," I noticed that this particular remedy has several ingredients in common; only the preparation of Cinnabar differs, and treatments vary. The condition treated here is frequent urination without control, accompanied by forgetfulness and persistent dreams. Noting these differences and investigating them thoroughly, one finds that this treatment method may not yield results.

    Moreover, generally speaking: the classics state that the kidneys govern the bowels, while the liver governs urination and micturition. The "Nan Jing" states that the small intestine corresponds to the red intestine. Hence, both the redness of the face and the color of the urine derive from the heart and the small intestine, with the southern region displaying red externally. The classics describe the lower burner as a drain, referring specifically to the excretion of both urine and feces. Feces are yang, representing tangible transformation and thus belong to the lower burner. The kidneys are considered to govern feces, without mentioning the large intestine, indicating that disturbances in this area are deemed renal disorders. Urination is yin, representing intangible transformation, and thus belongs to the upper aspect of the lower burner. The liver is considered to govern urination and micturition, also indicating disturbances in this context are regarded as issues of the bowel. All intangible transformations are under the governance of the bowels.[34p]

    诸有形气化者，皆脏病所主。此二证俱在下焦则同，但有形、无形，及在腑、在脏有殊，俱是丹田衰败。不言心火者，以其相火代行君之政令故也。细分之，则膀胱壬水胜丙火小肠者，不传入阴，故为泄血。泄血利不禁，为有形质病，且不传阴则阴不病。何为有形病？此为阴之体也，为腑之用也。天地阴阳，互为体用，以斯可见。是明五脏为六腑所用，六腑为五脏所用明矣。是有形皆为传阴。大小便不禁，是膀胱不禁为遗溺，此不传阴，是丹田胞络受寒，为壬所克。大抵诸腑皆乘有形，有形病者皆在腑，责其所乘皆在脏也。用伏火丹砂者，去其寒性耳。治法同者，以其俱在下焦，补诸无形，同在胞络耳；以其胞与肾相对，有渠相通故也。肾主大便，肝主小便。所治安得不殊？经曰：肾肝同归一治。又曰：少阳主骨，所生病，溲便难。膀胱主筋，所生病，亦可知也。小便不禁，茯苓汤下。大便不禁，米饮下。[35p]

    All entities with physical forms and vital energies are governed by organ diseases. When both conditions occur in the lower regions, they are the same, but whether they are tangible or intangible, and whether they relate to the bowels or the organs, varies. This is all due to the decline of the elixir field. The heart fire is not mentioned because its attendant fire carries out the edicts of the ruler. If we analyze further, the water of the bladder (associated with the yin) conquers the fire of the small intestine (associated with the yang); hence, it does not transmit to the yin, resulting in blood leakage. Blood leakage and excess urination are due to tangible physical maladies, and since it does not transfer to the yin, the yin remains unaffected. What is a tangible illness? This pertains to the substance of the yin and the function of the bowels. The interplay of heaven and earth, yin and yang, mutually defines substance and function, as can be observed. Thus it is clear that the five organs are utilized by the six bowels while the six bowels are also utilized by the five organs. All tangible matters ultimately relate to the transmission of the yin. Incontinence of urine and feces is due to the bladder's failure to retain, resulting in involuntary urination, which does not transmit to the yin. This is caused by the cold affecting the elixir field, being overcome by the water element (associated with the bladder). Generally, all bowels bear tangible forms, and tangible illnesses are found within the bowels, while the responsibility lies within the organs. The use of subdued fire and cinnabar serves merely to eliminate cold properties. The treatment methods are similar because they both reside in the lower regions, nourishing the intangible, as they are all within the elixir field; this is due to their connection to each other. The kidney governs defecation, and the liver governs urination. How can the treatments not be different? The classics state: the kidneys and liver are treated as one. It also states: the lesser yang governs the bones, and the resultant illnesses lead to difficulties in urination and defecation. The bladder governs the muscles, and the resulting illnesses can be understood likewise. For incontinence of urine, administer Poria Decoction. For incontinence of feces, administer Rice Drink.[35p]

    　　　　　小便不通

    　　小便不通，有气虚、血虚，有痰风闭实热。气虚用参、芪、升麻等先服后吐，或参、芪药中探吐之。血虚，四物汤先服后吐，或藭归汤中探吐亦可。痰多，二陈汤先服后吐。已上皆用探吐。若痰气闭塞，二陈汤加木通、香附探吐之，以提其气，气升则水自降，盖气承载其水也。有实热者当利之，砂糖汤调牵牛末二三分，或山栀之类。有热有湿有气结于下，宜清宜燥宜升。　　肾主水，膀胱为之腑。水潴于膀胱，而泄于小肠，实相通也。[36p]

    Urinary Obstruction

    Urinary obstruction can result from qi deficiency or blood deficiency, as well as phlegm and wind blocking, or from excess heat. For qi deficiency, one should first take ginseng, astragalus, and cimicifuga, and then induce vomiting, or induce vomiting with them mixed in the medicine. For blood deficiency, one can first take the Four Substance Decoction and then induce vomiting, or induce vomiting with liquoric and angelica blend. If there is an excess of phlegm, one should first take the Erchen Decoction and then induce vomiting. All of the above should use induced vomiting. If phlegm and qi are blocked, the Erchen Decoction should be prepared with muxiang and cyperus to help raise qi; when qi rises, water will naturally descend, as qi bears the water. For those with excess heat, it should be regulated; a syrup of sugar mixed with a few grams of morning glory root, or similar substances such as gardenia should be used. When there is heat and dampness, and qi is blocked below, it is important to clear, dry, and lift. The kidneys govern water, and the bladder is their organ. Water is retained in the bladder and is expelled through the small intestine, as they are interconnected.[36p]

    然小肠独应于心者，何哉？盖阴不可以无阳，水不可以无火，水火既济，上下相交，此荣卫所以流行，而水窦开阖，所以不失其司耳。惟夫心肾不交，阴阳不调，故内外关格而水道濇，传送失度而水道滑。热则不通，冷则不禁。其热盛者，小便闭而绝无。其热微者，小便难而仅有。肾与膀胱俱虚，客热乘之，故不能制水。水挟热而行濇，是以数起而溺有余沥。肾与膀胱俱冷，内气不充，故胞中自滑，所出多而色白，是以遇夜阴盛愈多矣。小便濇滑，又当调适其气。[37p]

    The small intestine uniquely responds to the heart; why is this so? It is because yin cannot exist without yang, and water cannot exist without fire. When water and fire are balanced, they interact up and down, thus enabling the flow of nourishment and defense, while the water passages open and close, preventing loss of their function. However, when the heart and kidneys do not interact, and yin and yang are out of balance, internal and external pathways are obstructed, leading to water retention and loss of proper function, thus causing the water path to become slippery. If there is excess heat, urination is obstructed entirely. With slight heat, urination becomes difficult and barely occurs. When both the kidneys and bladder are deficient, external heat can take over, hence they cannot regulate water. Water mixed with heat leads to slippery conditions, resulting in frequent urination with residual dribbling. When both the kidneys and bladder are cold and internal energy is insufficient, the passages become too loose, resulting in excessive output that is pale in color, which becomes more pronounced during the night when yin is stronger. The slippery nature of urination should also be addressed by adjusting the Qi.[37p]

    　　　　医学正传 【明　虞抟】

    　　　　　秘结论

    　　《内经》曰：北方黑色，入通于肾，开窍于二阴，藏精于肾。夫肾主五液，故肾实则津液足而大便滋润，肾虚则津液竭而大便燥结。原其所由，皆房劳过度，饮食失节。或恣饮酒浆，过食辛热。饮食之火起于脾胃，淫欲之火起于命门，以致火盛水亏，津液不生，故传道失常，渐成结燥之证。是故有风燥，有热燥，有阳结，有阴结，有气滞结；又有年高血少，津液枯涸，或因有所脱血，津液暴竭，种种不同，固难一例而推焉。经云：肾恶燥，急食辛以润之，以苦泄之。阳结者散之，阴结者温之。[38p]

    Medical Classic: A True Account by Yu Tuan (Ming Dynasty)

    Secret Conclusion

    The "Inner Canon" states: The northern region is associated with the color black, which connects to the kidneys, opens through the two lower orifices, and stores essence in the kidneys. The kidneys govern the five liquids; thus, when the kidneys are functioning well, bodily fluids are sufficient, and bowel movements are moist. When the kidneys are deficient, bodily fluids are depleted, leading to dry and hardened stools. This condition arises mainly from overindulgence in sexual activity and irregular dietary habits. Excessive consumption of alcohol and spicy foods can ignite heat in the spleen and stomach, while the heat from excessive desires arises from the life gate, resulting in an overabundance of fire and depletion of water, leading to insufficient production of bodily fluids. Consequently, there may be symptoms of dryness from wind, heat, or the stagnation of energy; additionally, aging and blood deficiency can lead to dryness of bodily fluids, or due to loss of blood, there may be extreme depletion of fluids. Such variations make it difficult to draw a single conclusion. The classic states: The kidneys despise dryness; thus, one should urgently consume spicy foods to moisten them and bitter foods to drain them. For yang stagnation, scatter it; for yin stagnation, warm it.[38p]

    大法治燥者，润之以大黄、当归、桃仁、麻子仁、(木郁)李仁之类。风燥者，加以防风、羌活、秦艽、皂荚之类。丸以炼蜜，取其润燥以助传导之势，故结散而疏通矣。仍多服补血生津之剂，助其真阴，固其根本，庶无再结之患。切勿以巴豆、牵牛等峻剂攻下。虽暂得通快，必致再结愈甚，反酿成病根胶固，卒难调治。或有血虚，脉大如葱管，发热而大便结燥者，甚不可发汗，汗之则重亡津液，闭结而死，此医杀之耳。《活人书》有脾约证，谓胃强脾弱，约束津液，不得四布，但输膀胱，故小便数而大便难，制脾约丸以下脾之结燥，使肠润结化，津流入胃而愈。[39p]

    For treating severe dryness, one should use ingredients like rhubarb, angelica, peach kernel, hemp seed, and (wooden) jujube kernel. For wind dryness, add materials such as saposhnikovia, notopterygium, gentiana, and soapberry. These should be made into pills with honey, aiming to moisture dryness and assist the movement, thus resolving blockages and promoting flow. Additionally, one should often take tonics for blood and fluid production to support the true yin and solidify the foundation, so as to avoid a recurrence of blockages. Never resort to harsh purgatives like croton seed or morning glory seeds. While this may provide temporary relief, it will inevitably lead to worse blockages and create a root of illness that becomes difficult to treat. If there is blood deficiency, with a pulse like a scallion stalk, fever, and dry, hard stools, one must absolutely avoid inducing sweat; doing so would deplete vital fluids, leading to closures that could be fatal—this would be akin to killing the patient. The "Living Person's Book" describes a condition of spleen constraint where the stomach is strong but the spleen is weak, restricting the fluids that cannot spread evenly, resulting only in the bladder receiving them, causing frequent urination and difficult bowel movements. The constraint must be resolved by using pills that address spleen deficiency, thereby lubricating the intestines to transform blockages and allowing fluids to flow into the stomach for recovery.[39p]

    　　　　　小便赤涩

    　　汗多而小便赤涩，暑月多有此证。盛暑所饮既多，小便反濇少而赤，缘上停为饮，外发于汗，津道不通，小肠濇闭，则水不运下。五苓散一名导逆，内有朮、桂收汗，猪苓、泽泻、茯苓分水道，收其在外者使之内，又从而利导焉。发者敛之，壅者通之，义取于此。然有虚劳汗多而小便赤涩者，却是五内枯燥，滋腴既去，不能生津，故溺涩而赤，不宜过用通小便之剂，竭其肾水，惟当温养润肺，十全大补汤、养荣汤之类选用。　　汗者心液。心主血，养血则心得所养，汗止津生，不待通溺而自清矣。诸失精血及患痈毒人，忽有小便赤涩之证，此亦是枯竭不润之故。[40p]

    Frequent Red and Turbid Urination

    When there is excessive sweating and the urine is red and turbid, this is often seen during the hot months. In the heat of summer, one drinks a lot, yet the urine becomes concentrated and red, as fluid accumulates in the upper body from drinking, and it is released outward through sweat. This obstruction in the fluid pathways causes the small intestine to be blocked, preventing proper downward movement of water.

    The formula Wuling San, also known as Daoni, contains ingredients such as Atractylodes and Cinnamon to reduce sweat, while Polyporus, Alisma, and Poria work to regulate the water pathways, drawing out what is outside to the inside, allowing for elimination. What needs to be reduced is gathered, and what is obstructed is opened—this is the principle behind it.

    However, in cases of deficiency leading to excessive sweating and red, turbid urine, it indicates that the internal organs are dried up. Once the nourishing essence is depleted, the body cannot produce fluids, leading to the turbid and red urine. It is inadvisable to excessively use diuretics, as they will drain kidney fluids. Instead, one should focus on warming and nourishing the lungs, selecting remedies such as Shi Quan Da Bu Tang or Yang Rong Tang.

    Sweat is a fluid of the heart. The heart governs blood, and nourishing the blood ensures the heart is nurtured. When sweating stops, fluids are generated naturally, without needing to rely on urination for cleansing. Those who have lost blood or are suffering from abscesses and toxins, and suddenly experience red and turbid urine, are also experiencing dryness and lack of moisture.[40p]

    　　　　证治要诀 【明　戴思恭】

    　　　　　大便秘

    　　有风秘、冷秘、气秘、热秘；又有老人津液干燥，是名虚证。妇人分产亡血，及发汗利小便，病后血气未复，皆能作秘，俱宜麻仁丸。风秘之病，由风搏肺脏，传于大肠，故传化难。或其人素有风病者，亦多有秘，宜小续命汤去附子倍芍药，入竹沥两蚬壳许。实者，吞脾约麻仁丸；虚者，吞养正丹。冷秘由冷气横于肠胃，凝阴固结，津液不通，胃道秘塞，其人肠内气攻，喜热恶寒，宜藿香正气散加枳壳、官桂各半钱，吞半硫丸。热药多秘，惟硫黄暖而通；冷药多泄，惟黄连肥肠而止泄。气秘由气不升降，谷气不行，其人多噫。宜苏子降气汤加枳壳吞养正丹，或半硫丸、来复丹。未效，佐以木香槟榔丸。[41p]

    Key Points of Diagnosis and Treatment

    Constipation

    There are various types of constipation: wind constipation, cold constipation, qi constipation, and heat constipation. Additionally, elderly individuals may experience dryness of bodily fluids, which is termed a deficiency condition. Women may face constipation due to postpartum blood loss, sweating, or frequent urination; in cases where the blood and qi have not yet recovered after illness, this can also lead to constipation. All cases are suitable for using Ma Ren Wan (Hemp Seed Pill).

    Wind constipation is caused by the wind affecting the lungs and spreading to the large intestine, making transformation difficult. Individuals with a history of wind ailments often experience constipation. It is advisable to use Xiao Xu Ming Tang (Minor Continuation of Life Decoction) with the amount of Fu Zi (Aconite) reduced and the amount of Shao Yao (Peony Root) increased, and to add approximately two shells of bamboo juice. For those with excess, take Ma Ren Wan; for those with deficiency, take Yang Zheng Dan (Nourishing Upright Elixir).

    Cold constipation occurs due to cold air obstructing the intestines and stomach, condensing yin and causing a blockage of fluids. When the stomach is obstructed, individuals experience gas in the intestines and tend to prefer warmth while disliking cold. It is advised to use Huo Xiang Zheng Qi San (Agastache Correct Qi Powder) with equal parts of Zhi Ke (Bitter Orange) and Guan Gui (Cinnamon), and take half of a sulfur pill.

    Heat medicine often leads to constipation; only sulfur is warming and promotes bowel movement. Cold medicines usually cause diarrhea; only Huang Lian (Coptis) is effective for stopping diarrhea by nourishing the intestines. Qi constipation arises from a failure of qi to rise and fall, leading to stagnation of food qi, often resulting in belching. The remedy includes Su Zi Jiang Qi Tang (Perilla Seed Decoction for Descending Qi) with added Zhi Ke and Yang Zheng Dan, or a half sulfur pill, or Lai Fu Dan (Turnip Pill). If these do not work, consider adding Mu Xiang Bing Lang Wan (Aucklandia and Areca Nut Pill).[41p]

    欲其速通，则枳壳生用。　　热秘，面赤身热，肠胃胀闷，时欲得冷，或口舌生疮，此由大肠热结，宜四顺清凉饮吞顺肠丸，或木香槟榔丸。有气作疼，大肠秘结，用通剂而便愈不通。又有秘气，强饮通之，虽通复闭。或迫之使通，因时下血者，此惟当顺气，气顺便自通。顺气之法，又当求温暖之剂。曾有下巴豆等药不通，进丹、附却通，不可不知。　　老人虚秘，反出汗利，小便过多。一切病后血气未复而秘者，宜苏子降气汤倍加归吞威灵仙丸，或肉黄饮、苁蓉顺肠丸尤宜。　　宿食留滞，结而不通，腹胀气急，胸中痞满，宜感应丸加巴豆。　　凡诸秘服药不通，或兼他证不受药者，用蜜皂角导。冷秘，生姜导亦佳。[42p]

    To achieve rapid relief, use bitter orange peel.

    In cases of heat constipation, with symptoms like a red face, body heat, abdominal bloating, occasional desires for coolness, or sores on the mouth and tongue, these arise from heat accumulation in the large intestine. It is advisable to take a cooling drink and swallow intestinal pills, or use a pill with agarwood and betel nut. If there's pain with gas, and the large intestine is obstructed, using a laxative will not help. If there is more of a wind-like blockage, forcing intake to relieve it may result in a recurrence of the blockage. In cases where blood is expelled alongside, one should focus on regulating the qi; once the qi flows smoothly, relief will follow. The method to regulate qi should also seek warm remedies.

    There have been instances where purgative herbs like bitter bean failed to work, while using Dan and Fu successfully led to relief; this knowledge is essential.

    For elderly individuals experiencing weak constipation, with symptoms like sweating, excessive urination, and lingering issues after illness, it is advisable to use a modified Suzi Qiangqi Decoction with increased doses of Gui and Weilingxian pill, or to consider Rouhuang drink or Condon broth for intestinal regulation.

    For food stagnation causing blockage, resulting in abdominal bloating, gas, and a feeling of fullness in the chest, it is recommended to use Gan Ying Pills with bitter bean.

    In general, if medications for constipation do not work, or if there are other symptoms preventing effective treatment, use honey and soap pod as a guide. For cold-related constipation, ginger can also be an effective guide.[42p]

    　　　　　闭癃

    　　古名曰癃者，罢也。不通为癃。不约为遗。小便滴沥濇痛者，谓之淋。小便急满不通者，谓之闭。宜五苓散、灯心汤调服。暑月多有此患，止宜本药。闭而不通，脐下胀为癃闭，以灯心汤调五苓散，或洗慈汤调独味琥珀末；仍令其以盐填脐下，更滴之以水。　　若服凉药不效，审是冷秘，宜炒盐熨其小腹，或洗慈汤熏洗。有腹急而小便不通，愈用通剂愈甚，宜以盐实脐中，就盐上灼艾十来壮。[43p]

    Closed Urination

    In ancient times, this condition, known as "lóng," means to cease. It occurs when there is obstruction; not passing urine is referred to as losing it. If urination is painful, dripping, and lingering, it is called "lín." If the urge to urinate is urgent but blocked, it is termed "closed." One should take Wu Ling San or Deng Xin Tang as adjustments. This condition is often prevalent in hot months, and the original medicine should be prescribed.

    When there is obstruction and the lower abdomen feels bloated, it is diagnosed as closed lóng. One should use Deng Xin Tang to adjust with Wu Ling San, or prepare a wash with Ci Tang mixed with powdered amber; additionally, one should place salt in the lower abdomen and apply water. If cooling medicine does not work, it may be due to chilling stagnation. In such cases, one should apply roasted salt to the lower abdomen, or use Ci Tang for steam washing.

    If there is abdominal urgency with blocked urination, the more one uses laxatives, the worse it gets. It is advisable to fill the navel with salt and then burn moxa directly on the salt for better effect.[43p]

    　　　　　频数遗尿

    　　小便多者，乃下元虚冷，肾不摄水，以致渗泄。宜菟丝子丸、八味丸、元兔丹、生料鹿茸丸。　　有人每日从早至午前，定尿四次，一日之间，又自无事，此肾虚所致。亦犹脾肾泄，早泄而晚愈，次日又复然者也。　　若小便常急，遍数虽多，而所出常少，放了复急，不濇痛，却非淋证，亦有小便毕，少顷忽再出些，少者多因自忍尿，或忍尿行房事而然。宜生料五苓散减泽泻之半，加阿胶一钱，吞八味丸。此丸须用五味子者。　　睡着遗尿者，此亦下元冷，小便无禁而然。宜大菟丝子丸，猪胞炙碎煎汤下。　　有盛喜致小便多，日夜无度，乃喜极伤心，心与小肠为表里。宜分清饮、四七汤各半贴和煎；仍以辰砂妙香散，吞小菟丝子丸或元兔丹。　　小便不禁，出而不觉，赤者有热，白者气虚也。[44p]

    Frequent Urination

    Excessive urination indicates deficiency and coldness in the lower yuan, with the kidneys failing to retain water, leading to leakage. Suitable remedies include Tu Si Zi Wan, Ba Wei Wan, Yuan Tu Dan, and Sheng Liao Lu Rong Wan. Some people urinate four times between morning and noon daily, yet they have no other issues; this is caused by kidney deficiency. It is similar to the spleen and kidney deficiency where there is early leakage but late recovery, recurring the next day.

    If urination is often urgent, although the frequency may be high, the amount is typically small. After urinating, urgency returns quickly without pain—this is not a case of dysuria. It may also happen that after urination, there is a sudden need to urinate again, often due to holding back urine or during sexual activity. For this, reduce half of the Ze Xie in Sheng Liao Wu Ling San and add one qian of E Jiao, then take Ba Wei Wan. This pill must contain Wu Wei Zi.

    Those who wet the bed while asleep are also experiencing coldness in the lower yuan, resulting in unrestrained urination. For this, take Da Tu Si Zi Wan and boil crushed pig bladder for decoction.

    If excessive joy leads to frequent urination, day and night without restraint, it indicates that extreme happiness harms the heart, which is connected to the small intestine in mutual correspondence. A remedy is to blend equal parts of Qing Drink and Si Qi Tang for decoction; also, take Chen Sha Miao Xiang San and swallow small Tu Si Zi Wan or Yuan Tu Dan.

    Uncontrollable urination that occurs without awareness, with red urine indicating heat, while white urine hints at qi deficiency.[44p]

    　　　　明医杂着 【明　王纶】

    　　　　　不禁频数

    　　小便不禁或频数，古方多以为寒，而用温濇之药。殊不知属热者，盖膀胱火邪妄动，水不得宁，故不能禁而频数来也。故年老人多频数者，是膀胱血少，阳火偏旺也。治法当补膀胱阴血，泻火邪为主，而佐以收濇之剂，如牡蛎、山茱萸、五味子之类，不可用温药也。病本属热，故宜泻火。因水不足，故火动而致小便多。小便既多，水益虚矣。故宜补血泻火，治其本也；收之濇之，治其标也。[45p]

    Ming Medicine Miscellaneous Writings by Wang Lun

    Frequent Urination

    Frequent or uncontainable urination is often attributed to cold by ancient prescriptions, leading to the use of warming, astringent medicines. However, it should be understood that this condition can also belong to heat, in which case it is due to the chaotic movement of bladder fire, preventing water from stabilizing, resulting in frequent urination. Hence, elderly individuals frequently experience this condition due to a lack of bladder blood and excessive yang fire. The treatment should primarily involve replenishing the bladder's yin blood and dispelling the heat evil, complemented with astringent remedies such as oyster shell, cornelian cherry, and Schisandra fruit. Warming medicines should be avoided. The disease fundamentally stems from heat, thus heat should be dispelled. Additionally, insufficient water leads to active fire, causing increased urination. With frequent urination, water becomes even more depleted. Therefore, it is essential to replenish blood and dispel fire to treat the underlying issue, while using astringent measures to address the symptoms.[45p]

    　　　　医学纲目 【明　楼英】

    　　　　　闭癃

    　　闭癃，合而言之一病也，分而言之，有暴久之殊。盖闭者，暴病为溺闭，点滴不出，俗名小便不通是也。癃者，久病为溺癃，淋沥点滴而出，一日数十次或百次，名淋病是也。　　小便不通，腹下痛，状如覆碗，痛闷难忍者，乃肠胃干涸，膻中气不下。故经所谓：膀胱者，州都之官，津液藏焉，气化则能出矣。故膻中者臣使之官，三焦相火，肾为气海也。王注曰：膀胱津液之腑，胞内居之，处少腹间毛内。若得气海之气施化，则溲便注下。气海之气不及，则隐秘不通，故不得便利也。先用木香、沉香各三钱，酒调下，或八正散。甚则宜上涌之，令气通达，便自通利。经所谓：病在下，上取之。王注曰：热攻于上，不利于下。气盛于上，则辛温散之，苦以利之。　　小腹痛胀，如覆碗为实。其法有二：气壅塞于下者，用吐法以提之。血瘀于下者，用桃仁之类以破之。[46p]

    Medical Compendium
    (Ming Dynasty, Lou Ying)

    Urinary Retention

    Urinary retention, broadly speaking, is one disease that can be divided into two distinct types: acute and chronic. The acute form occurs when there is sudden inability to urinate, known colloquially as urinary obstruction. The chronic form refers to persistent difficulty urinating, where drops trickle out multiple times a day, often called dysuria.

    When there is urinary obstruction, pain is felt in the lower abdomen, similar to the sensation of a bowl turned upside down—painful and difficult to endure. This condition arises because the intestines and stomach are dried up, and the qi in the chest does not descend. As stated in the classics: "The bladder is the government of the region, where fluids are stored; when qi is transformed, it can be released." The chest area is overseen by the ministerial fire and the kidneys serve as the sea of qi. Wang's commentary states: "The bladder is an organ of fluids, located within the lower abdomen, between the hairs of the lower belly. If the qi of the sea is allowed to transform, then urination will be smooth. If the qi is insufficient, there will be obstructions, and thus relief cannot be attained."

    To treat this condition, use three qian each of clove and sandalwood, mixed with wine, or use the Eight Correcting Powder. In severe cases, it is advisable to stimulate upwards to facilitate the passage of qi, leading to natural relief. As mentioned in the classics: "If the disease is in the lower part, take measures from above." Wang's commentary further explains: "Heat attacking from above hinders below. When qi is abundant above, use warming and dispersing agents, and rely on bitter herbs to assist in relief."

    If the lower abdomen is painful and distended, giving a sensation of fullness, there are two methods of treatment: if qi is stagnant below, employ vomiting techniques to lift it; if there is blood stasis below, use substances like桃仁 (peach kernel) to break it up.[46p]

    　　　　　不利

    　　经云：肾合膀胱，膀胱者津液之腑也。小肠属肾，肾上连肺，故将两脏。三焦者，中渎之腑也，水液出焉。是属膀胱，乃肾之腑也。又云：膀胱者，州都之官，津液藏焉，气化则能出矣。由是言之，膀胱藏水，三焦出水。治小便不利，故刺灸法但取三焦穴，不取膀胱也。小肠属肾肺，故东垣用清肺饮子、滋肾丸利小便是也。[47p]

    Unfavorable Conditions

    The texts state: The kidneys connect with the bladder, and the bladder is the organ for fluids. The small intestine is associated with the kidneys, which are connected to the lungs; hence, they are considered two organs. The Sanjiao (Triple Burner) is the organ of the central duct, where fluids are produced. It is associated with the bladder, which is an organ of the kidneys. It also states: The bladder is the official governing the provinces, where fluids are stored; when they are vaporized, they can be released. From this, we understand that the bladder stores water, and the Sanjiao releases water. To treat difficult urination, therefore, acupuncture and moxibustion methods focus only on the Sanjiao points, not the bladder. The small intestine is related to the kidneys and lungs; hence Dongyuan uses Qingfeiyin (Clear Lung Decoction) and Zhirenwan (Kidney Nourishing Pill) to promote urination.[47p]

    　　　　医学入门 【明　李梴】

    　　　　　大便燥结

    　　燥有风燥、热燥、火燥、气血虚燥，详燥门。结有能食脉实数者为阳结，不能食脉弦微者为阴结；亦有年高气血虚结者。　　燥属少阴津液不足，辛以润之。结属太阴有燥粪，苦以泻之。凡结后仍服润血生津之剂，免其再结再通，愈伤元气。　　湿热怫郁，心腹胀满，有虫积者，槟榔丸。凡燥结有时者为实，无时者为虚。有药石毒者，大小便闭，气胀如鼓者，三和散合三黄汤。饮食毒者，香连丸。胃火者，白虎汤。　　津少，因发汗利小便过多，及产后失血等证。血液枯者，五仁丸、肾气丸、大补阴丸，或导滞通幽汤加槟榔、条芩、陈皮。气虚者参仁丸、补中益气汤。挟七情者，古苁沉丸。　　脏寒则气滞，脏冷则血枯。[48p]

    Introduction to Medicine by Li Zhan (Ming Dynasty)

    Dry and Hard Stools

    Dryness can be categorized as wind-dryness, heat-dryness, fire-dryness, and qi and blood deficiency-dryness, which are detailed in the section on dryness. Hardness can be classified as yang hardness, where one can feel the pulse strongly, and yin hardness, where the pulse is weak and thin; there are also cases of aging with qi and blood deficiency. Dryness relates to the deficiency of yin fluids in the lesser yin organs, which can be moistened with pungent herbs. Hardness relates to the greater yin being associated with dry feces, which can be purged with bitter herbs. After a hardness has occurred, one should continue to take blood-nourishing and fluid-generating medicines to prevent recurrence and to avoid further harm to the original energy.

    For damp-heat problems with fullness in the heart and abdomen, and with accumulated worms, one can use Borneo nut pills. When dryness and hardness occur sporadically, it indicates a real condition; when it is constant, it indicates a虚 (insubstantial condition). In cases complicated by toxins from drugs and stones, with urinary retention and abdominal distension, one can use Sanhe Powder combined with Sanhuang Decoction. In cases of food poisoning, one can use Xianglian Pills. If there is stomach fire, Baihu Decoction is appropriate.

    Deficiency of fluids can arise from excessive sweating, overuse of diuretics, and postpartum blood loss. When blood is desiccated, one can use Wuren Pills, Shenqi Pills, or Dashengxie Pills, or Dai Zhi Tong You Decoction mixed with Borneo nut, Coptis, and dried tangerine peel. For qi deficiency, one can use Shenren Pills or Buzhong Yiqi Decoction. For those affected by emotional disturbances, Guocongchen Pills may be helpful.

    Cold in the organs leads to qi stagnation, and cold in the organs leads to blood desiccation.[48p]

    有痃癖冷气结滞者，古半硫丸、古姜附汤、五积散，冰冷与之。其病虽宜服阳药，若大便不通者，当暂与润剂以微通之，不令闭结。　　七情气闭，后重窘迫者，三和散、六磨汤。脉浮昼便难者，陈皮、杏仁等分蜜丸服；脉沉夜便难者，换桃仁。　　痰滞不通者，二陈汤加枳壳、槟榔。　　伤热物者，三黄丸。伤寒物者，丁香脾积丸，通用大黄备急丸。有脾胃伏火者，润肠丸。　　燥结当用流行肺气，肺与大肠为表里故也。枳梗汤加紫苏，或苏子降气汤，或苏子、麻仁煮粥。又如脾约证，胃强脾弱，约束津液，不能四布，但输膀胱，故小便数而大便难，此脾约丸之由制也。但脾属阴，虚火燔金，耗则肺失传化，尤宜滋阴养血。在西北壮实者，以脾约丸开结可也；东南气血虚者，润燥为主。　　通用冷热熨法、淹脐法、麻油导法。[49p]

    For those with cold-induced stagnation or phlegm accumulation, the ancient Half-Sulfur Pill, Ancient Ginger and Aconite Decoction, and Wujisan are recommended, paired with something cold. Although these conditions may require yang medicine, if there's constipation, one should temporarily use a laxative to gently encourage movement without causing blockage.

    In cases of emotional stagnation and heaviness, use Sanhe Powder or Liumo Decoction. For a floating pulse with difficulty in daytime bowel movements, Chenpi and Xingren can be prepared in honey pills; for a sinking pulse with difficulty at night, use Taoren instead.

    For phlegm stagnation, Erchen Decoction with Zhiqiao and Binglang is effective. For heat injuries, use Sanhuang Pill. For cold damage, consider Dingxiang Pizhi Pill or the emergency Dahuang Preparation. If there is spleen and stomach fire, use Runchang Pill.

    For dry obstructions, apply treatments that promote lung qi, as the lungs and large intestines are interconnected. Zhiqiao Decoction with Zisu, or Suzi Jiangqi Decoction, or porridge made from Suzi and Mairen can be effective. Additionally, in cases of spleen deficiency where the stomach is strong but the spleen weak, causing fluids to be trapped and difficult to distribute, this leads to frequent urination and difficult bowel movements, explaining the need for Spleen Deficiency Pills.

    However, since the spleen is yin, excessive heat can consume it, causing the lungs to lose their ability to transform and transport, hence nourishing yin and replenishing blood is crucial. For strong individuals in the northwest, Spleen Deficiency Pills can relieve blockage; in contrast, those in the southeast with qi and blood deficiency should focus on moisture and nourishment.

    Methods such as applying hot or cold compresses, immersion up to the navel, or using sesame oil for medicinal purposes are beneficial.[49p]

    　　　　　小便不通

    　　经曰：膀胱不利为癃，候其鼻头色黄者，小便必难。肾主水，畜于膀胱，泄于小肠，实相通也。然肾应于心，心火盛则小肠热结。热微则小便难而仅有，热甚则小便闭而绝无。宜清热生津为主，单(石卜)硝散、五苓散。脐下胀者加琥珀；或单号珀为末蜜丸，人参茯苓煎汤下；或捣生车前子自然汁，入蜜一匙调服。有利大便行后而小便不利者，八正散加木香。热盛茎中濇痛者，导赤散加山栀、大黄，或麻子仁丸、冷热熨法。[50p]

    Difficulty of Urination

    The classic text states: When the bladder is not functioning properly, it leads to urine retention. If the nostrils are yellow in color, urination will be difficult. The kidneys govern water, storing it in the bladder and releasing it into the small intestine, which are interconnected. However, the kidneys correspond to the heart; if heart fire is excessive, it leads to heat and stagnation in the small intestine. If the heat is mild, urination becomes difficult with minimal output; if the heat is severe, urination may cease completely. The treatment should focus on clearing heat and generating fluids, using such formulas as Shibu San and Wu Ling San. If there is distension below the navel, add amber; alternatively, prepare an amber powder into honey pills, or decoct ginseng and poria to take. For those who notice improved bowel movements but still experience difficulty urinating, use Ba Zheng San with added aromatic wood. If there's severe pain in the urethra due to excessive heat, use Dao Chi San with added gardenia and rhubarb, or take Ma Zi Ren Wan, along with heat-cooling compress methods.[50p]

    　　虚损久病自汗，五内枯燥，及诸疮失血过多，人参养荣汤。有精竭不痛茎痒，八味丸。有胃弱不能通调水道，下输膀胱及气虚，四君子汤加黄芪、升麻。有脾枯亡血，及劳伤血虚，四物汤。气血俱虚，八物汤。　　痰涎阻滞，气道不通者，导痰汤加升麻。　　忿怒气结，闭遏不通者，二陈汤加木香、香附、木通，俱先服一盏；后煎滓探吐以提其气，气升则水自降矣。实热，砂糖调牵牛末一二钱探吐。　　上热者，导赤散加黄连灯心。下虚者，滋肾丸。上盛下虚者，清心莲子饮。[51p]

    For those suffering from prolonged illness with spontaneous sweating, internal dryness, and excessive blood loss from ulcers, use the Ginseng Nourishing Decoction. For cases of depleted essence with no pain but itching in the genitals, use the Eight Ingredients Pill. If there is stomach weakness preventing the regulation of water pathways and qi deficiency affecting the bladder, use the Four Gentlemen Decoction with added Astragalus and Scutellaria. For spleen deficiency due to blood loss and exhaustion from overwork leading to blood deficiency, use the Four Substance Decoction. When both qi and blood are deficient, use the Eight Substance Decoction.

    For phlegm and fluids obstructing the qi pathways, use the Phlegm Resolving Decoction with added Scutellaria. If anger causes qi stagnation with blockage, use the Two Aged Decoction with added Saussurea and Cyperus, taking a cup first; then decoct the residue to induce vomiting to lift the qi, allowing water to descend naturally. In cases of real heat, use sugar with a small amount of bindweed to induce vomiting.

    For upper heat conditions, use the Guide Red Powder with added Coptis and lotus seed. For lower deficiency, use the Kidney Nourishing Pill. For upper excess and lower deficiency, use the Clear Heart Lotus Seed Drink.[51p]

    　　　　　小便不禁

    　　实热乃膀胱火动，四苓散合三黄汤加五味子、山茱萸少许。血虚，四苓散合四物汤加山栀、升麻。　　虚乃肾与膀胱气虚，十全大补汤加益智仁，或缩泉丸、大菟丝子丸、二苓丸。遇夜阴盛愈多，内虚自汗者，秘元丹。内虚湿热者，肾气丸，八味丸减泽泻、附子，加五味子、杜仲、故纸，倍山茱萸。虚寒冷者，古桂汤，大菟丝子丸加肉桂。　　劳心不禁者，妙香散、桑螵蛸散。劳役伤脾者，补中益气汤。　　下虚内损，则膀胱不约，便溺自遗，或尿后余沥，皆火盛水不得宁。治宜补膀胱阴血，泻火邪为主，而佐以山茱萸、牡蛎、五味子之类，不可温药。古方补阴丸最妙。妇人产后伤胞，小儿胞冷，鸡(月坒)胵散主之。[52p]

    Frequent Urination

    The condition of frequent urination is due to heat in the bladder causing agitation. Use a combination of Four Ling Powder and San Huang Decoction, adding a small amount of Schisandra and Cornelian Cherry. If there's blood deficiency, use a combination of Four Ling Powder and Four Substance Decoction, adding Gardenia and Cimicifuga.

    For deficiency of Kidney and Bladder energy, combine Shen Qi Decoction with Yi Zhi Ren, or use Suo Quan Pill, Da Tu Si Zi Pill, or Er Ling Pill. If symptoms worsen at night with increased Yin, or if there is internal deficiency with spontaneous sweating, use Mi Yuan Dan. For internal deficiency with damp heat, use Shen Qi Pill or Ba Wei Pill, reducing Ze Xie and Fu Zi, while adding Schisandra, Eucommia, and Rehmannia, and doubling the Cornelian Cherry. For deficiency with cold, use Gu Gui Decoction, and combine Da Tu Si Zi Pill with Cinnamon.

    For those whose frequent urination is due to mental strain, use Miao Xiang San or Sang Qiao Xiao San. If the spleen is damaged by overwork, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction.

    In cases of internal damage leading to frequent urination, the bladder cannot hold, resulting in involuntary urination or dribbling after urination, often due to excess fire and unrelenting water. Treatment should focus on nourishing the bladder’s Yin blood, clearing excess fire, while adding support from Cornelian Cherry, Oyster Shell, and Schisandra, avoiding warming herbs. The ancient formula for replenishing Yin Pills is most effective. For women, postpartum bladder injury, and for children with cold bladder, use Ji (Ming) Zhang Powder.[52p]

    　　　　医宗必读 【明　李中梓】

    　　　　　大便不通

    　　玩《内经》之言，则知大便秘结，专责之少阴一经。证状虽殊，总之津液枯干，一言以蔽之也。分而言之，则有胃实、胃虚、热秘、冷秘、风秘、气秘之分。胃实而秘者，善饮食，小便赤，麻仁丸、十宣丸之类。胃虚而秘者，不能饮食，小便清利，厚朴汤。热秘者，面赤见热，六脉数实，肠胃胀闷，时欲得冷，或口舌生疮，四顺清凉饮、润肠丸、木香槟榔丸。实者，承气汤。冷秘者，面白或黑，六脉沉迟，小便清白，喜热恶冷，藿香正气散加官桂、枳壳，吞半硫丸。气秘者，气不升降，谷气不行，其人多噫，苏子降气汤加枳壳，吞养正丹；未效，佐以木香槟榔丸。风秘者，风搏肺脏，传于大肠，小续命汤去附子倍芍药加竹沥，吞润肠丸或活血润肠丸。[53p]

    Essential Readings on Medicine
    By Li Zhongzi (Ming Dynasty)

    Constipation

    Studying the teachings of the "Inner Canon," one learns that constipation is primarily attributed to the lesser yin meridian. Although symptoms may vary, they generally stem from desiccated fluids. In detail, there are different types: fullness in the stomach, deficiency in the stomach, heat constipation, cold constipation, wind constipation, and qi constipation.

    For fullness in the stomach leading to constipation, symptoms include good appetite, red urine, and treatment with formulations like Ma Ren Wan or Shi Xuan Wan. In cases of deficiency in the stomach, where appetite is poor and urine is clear, one can use Hou Po Tang.

    Heat constipation presents with a flushed face, rapid pulse, bloating in the stomach and intestines, a desire for cold, or sores in the mouth, treated with Si Shun Qing Liang Yin, Run Chang Wan, or Mu Xiang Bing Lang Wan. For fullness, use Cheng Qi Tang.

    Cold constipation is marked by a pale or dark face, slow and deep pulse, clear urine, preference for warmth, and aversion to cold, treated with Huo Xiang Zheng Qi San, adding Gui Zhi and Zhi Ke, or swallowing Ban Liu Wan.

    Qi constipation results from stagnation of qi, characterized by bloating and excessive belching, treated with Su Zi Jiang Qi Tang plus Zhi Ke, or swallowing Yang Zheng Dan; if ineffective, complement with Mu Xiang Bing Lang Wan.

    Wind constipation is due to wind affecting the lungs, transferring to the large intestine, addressed with Xiao Xue Ming Tang, reducing Fu Zi and increasing Shao Yao, and swallowing Run Chang Wan or Huo Xue Run Chang Wan.[53p]

    更有老年津液干枯，妇人产后亡血，及发汗利小便，病后血气未复，皆能秘结。法当补养气血，使津液生则自通。误用硝黄利药，多致不救，而巴豆牵牛，其害更速。八珍汤加苏子、橘红、杏仁、苁蓉，倍用当归。若病证虽属阴寒，而脉实微躁，宜温暖药中略加苦寒，以去热躁，躁止勿加。如阴躁欲坐井中者，两尺按之必虚，或沉细而迟，但煎理中汤，待极冷方服；或服药不应，不敢用峻猛之药者，宜蜜煎导之。用盐五分，皂角末五分，入蜜煎中，其功更捷。冷秘者，酱生姜导之，或于蜜煎中加草乌头末。有热者，猪胆汁导之。久虚者，如常饮食法煮猪血脏汤，加酥食之。血仍润血，脏仍润脏，此妙法也。每见江湖方士，轻用硝黄者十伤四五，用巴丑者十伤七八，不可不谨也。或久而愈结，或变为肺痿吐脓血，或饮食不进而死。[54p]

    Moreover, in the elderly, the body fluids may dry up; in women, there can be blood loss after childbirth; sweating and frequent urination may occur; and those who have recovered from illness may not fully regain their vitality, which can all lead to blockages. The method should be to nourish the qi and blood so that the body fluids can replenish and flow freely. Misusing harsh laxatives can often result in dire consequences, and the harm from substances like croton seed is even more rapid. The Eight Treasure Decoction should be augmented with perilla seed, tangerine peel, apricot kernels, and cynomorium, and the amount of angelica should be doubled. If the condition is associated with yin-cold, but the pulse is solid and slightly agitated, it is advisable to add a slight amount of warming herbs mixed with bitter cold to dispel heat and agitation, while preventing further increase in anxiety. If the yin is agitated and feels like sitting in a well, pressing down two inches will yield a sensation of vacuity, or the pulse may be thin and slow; in such cases, one should prepare the decoction and wait until it is extremely cold before consuming it. If the medicine does not produce the expected response and one does not dare to use drastic measures, one should consider using honey to prepare it. Adding five grams of salt and five grams of locust bean powder to the honey preparation will enhance its effectiveness. For cold blockages, ginger juice or fresh ginger may be used to guide it; or add a small quantity of aconite powder to the honey decoction. For heat conditions, pig bile should be used. In cases of prolonged deficiency, as a common dietary method, one should boil pig blood and organs and consume them with ghee. Blood continues to nourish blood, and organs continue to nourish organs; this is a marvelous method. I frequently observe that those in the countryside who casually use harsh laxatives suffer serious injuries in about 40% of cases, while those using croton seeds face severe harm in about 70-80% of cases; caution is imperative. Either over time the condition worsens into blockages, or it transforms into pulmonary tuberculosis with pus and blood, or results in the inability to eat and subsequent death.[54p]

    　　　　　小便闭癃

    　　闭与癃，二证也。新病为溺闭，盖点滴难通也。久病为溺癃，盖屡出而短少也。闭癃之病，《内经》分肝与督脉、三焦与膀胱四经。然太阳膀胱但主藏溺，其主出溺者皆肝经及督脉及三焦也。又考膀胱为州都之官，津液藏焉，气化则能出矣。夫主气化者，太阴肺经也。若使肺燥不能生水，则气化不及州都，法当清金润肺，车前、紫菀、麦冬、茯苓、桑皮之类。如脾湿不运而精不上升，故肺不能生水，法当燥脾健胃，苍朮、白朮、茯苓、半夏之类。如肾水燥热，膀胱不利，法当滋肾涤热，黄蘗、知母、茯苓、泽泻、通草之类。夫滋肾泻膀胱，名为正治。清金润燥，名为隔二之治。健胃燥脾，名为隔三之治。[55p]

    Urinary Retention and Urinary Dysfunction

    Urinary retention and dysfunction are two conditions. In acute cases, it is called urinary retention, characterized by difficulty in urination. In chronic cases, it is referred to as urinary dysfunction, where there are frequent but scanty urinations. The conditions of retention and dysfunction are categorized in the "Inner Classic" into the liver and the governor vessel, the sanjiao and the bladder channels. However, the taiyang bladder primarily governs the storage of urine, while its expulsion is the responsibility of the liver channel, the governor vessel, and the sanjiao.

    Furthermore, the bladder is considered the official for the distribution of fluids; when the fluids are transformed, they can be expelled. The channel responsible for transformation is the taiyin lung channel. If the lung is dry and cannot generate fluids, then the transformation cannot effectively reach the distribution organ. The treatment should focus on clearing the metal and nourishing the lungs, using herbs such as plantago, aster, ophiopogon, poria, and mulberry bark.

    If the spleen is damp and fails to ascend essence, the lungs will be unable to generate fluids. In this case, the treatment should aim to dry the spleen and strengthen the stomach, using herbs like dahurian angelica, white atractylodes, poria, and pinellia. If kidney water is dry and heated, leading to ineffective bladder function, the approach should be to nourish the kidneys and clear heat, using herbs such as phellodendron, anemarrhena, poria, alisma, and tetrapanax.

    Thus, nourishing the kidneys and draining the bladder is termed the appropriate treatment. Clearing the metal and moistening dryness is known as the second-tier treatment. Strengthening the stomach and drying the spleen is referred to as the third-tier treatment.[55p]

    又或有水液只渗大肠，小肠因而燥竭，宜以淡渗之品，茯苓、猪苓、通草、泽泻之类，分利而已。或有气滞不能通调水道，下输膀胱者，顺气为急，根壳、木通、橘红之类。有实热者，非与纯阴之剂，则阳无以化。上焦热者，栀子、黄芩；中焦热者，黄连、芍药；下焦热者，黄蘗、知母。有大虚者，非与温补之剂，则水不能行，如金匮肾气丸，及补中益气汤是也。丹溪尝曰：吾以吐法通小便，譬如滴水之器，上窍闭则下窍无以自通，必上窍开而下窍之水出焉。气虚者，补中益气汤，先服后吐。血虚者，芎归汤，先服后吐。痰多者，二陈汤，先服后吐。气闭者，香附、木通探吐。更有瘀血而小便闭者，牛膝、桃仁为要药。《别录》云：小便不利，审是气虚，独参汤如神。由是观之，则受病之源，自非一途。若不从望闻问切，察之明，审之当，而浪投药剂，几何不以人命为戏耶！[56p]

    Additionally, if there is only moisture seeping into the large intestine, leading to dryness in the small intestine, one should use mild diuretics such as Poria, Polyporus, Rhemannia, and Alisma, mainly for drainage. If there is qi stagnation preventing the regulation of water pathways, resulting in water flowing down to the bladder, it is urgent to smooth the qi with herbs like Rhizoma, Akebia, and Tangerine Peel. In the case of actual heat, unless using purely Yin agents, Yang cannot be transformed. For heat in the upper jiao, use Gardenia and Scutellaria; for heat in the middle jiao, use Coptis and Peony; for heat in the lower jiao, use Berberine and Anemarrhena. If there is significant deficiency, without using warming and tonifying agents, water cannot flow, such as with Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan and Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang. Dan Xi once said: “I use the technique of vomiting to help urination, comparable to a water droplet vessel; if the upper orifice is closed, the lower orifice cannot open, hence it is essential for the upper orifice to open in order for the water below to flow.” For qi deficiency, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, first ingesting then purging. For blood deficiency, use Xiong Gui Tang, also first ingesting before purging. For excessive phlegm, use Er Chen Tang, similarly first ingesting then purging. For qi obstruction, use Xiang Fu and Mu Tong to aid in purging. Moreover, if there is stagnant blood leading to urinary obstruction, use Achyranthes and Peach Kernel as primary herbs. The "Prescription of Distinct Records" states: “If urination is hindered, one must diagnose whether it is qi deficiency; Shen Qi Tang is effective.” From this, it can be observed that the origin of the illness does not come from a single pathway. If one does not follow the principles of observation, listening, inquiry, and palpation, attentively assessing and judging, and recklessly administers medications, how could it not be a game with human lives?[56p]

    　　　　　小便不禁

    　　世俗之治小便不禁者，但知补濇而已。不知《内经》论肝、肾、膀胱之病，不指为何邪所干，则知七情六气，皆能为病也。又言手太阴虚者，为子母相关之病，则知所生、所胜、所不胜之五邪，皆足以为病也。总其大要而言，肺者主气，以下降生水，则下输膀胱者，津液藏焉，气化则能出。水泉不止者，膀胱不藏也。此两经者，实为总司。肺虚者为上虚，当补气，补中益气汤；不愈，当以黄蘗、生地、麦门冬清其热。膀胱虚者，为下虚，当濇脱，桑螵蛸、鸡(月坒)胵之类。挟寒者，家韭子丸、固脬丸、白茯苓散、菟丝子散之类。滑脱者，牡蛎丸。挟热者，白薇散或鸡肠散。更有睡则遗尿，皆责之虚，所以婴儿脬气未固，老人下元不足，多有此证。在婴儿挟热者，十居七八；在老人挟寒者，十居七八，此又不可不辨也。宜大菟丝子丸，猪脬炙研碎，煎汤送下。更须审寒热而为之活法。[57p]

    Incontinence

    In the ordinary management of incontinence, people only know to supplement the deficiency. They do not understand that the "Inner Canon" discusses the diseases of the liver, kidneys, and bladder without pointing to the specific evil that afflicts them. It is known that the seven emotions and six influences can all cause illness. It is also said that when the hand Taiyin is deficient, it relates to the mother-child connection in disease, indicating that the five evils, whether produced, counteracted, or uncounteracted, can all lead to illness.

    To summarize the key points: the lungs govern Qi, which facilitates the generation of fluids, distributing them to the bladder where bodily fluids are stored, and through transformation can be released. If the water source does not stop, the bladder does not retain. These two channels are fundamentally responsible for regulation. A deficiency in the lungs indicates an upper deficiency; thus, one should tonify Qi with a formula like Ren Shen Bai Du San. If not improved, Huang Lian, Sheng Di, and Mai Men Dong should be used to clear the heat.

    A deficiency in the bladder indicates a lower deficiency; therefore, one should use supplements like Sang Piao Xiao or similar types. In cases accompanied by cold, use Jia Jiu Zi Wan, Gu Pao Wan, Bai Fu Ling San, or Tu Si Zi San. For slippery and variable presentations, use Mu Li Wan. If there is accompanying heat, Bai Wei San or Ji Chang San can be utilized.

    There are also cases of nocturnal enuresis that are attributed to deficiency, where infants may have fragile bladder Qi and the elderly may have insufficient lower origin, leading to numerous such conditions. In infants, those with heat account for about 70-80%; in the elderly, those with cold also account for about the same percentage. This differentiation cannot be overlooked.

    It is advisable to prepare a large dose of Tu Si Zi Wan, crush roasted pig bladder, and decoct it to take. Additionally, one must carefully assess the presence of cold or heat to determine the appropriate treatment method.[57p]

    　　　　　伤寒小便不通

    　　已汗复下，小便不利，心烦，小柴胡汤。太阳汗后，脉浮，小便不利，微热而渴，五苓散。身黄，小便不利，腹微满者，茵陈蒿汤。小便不利，大便乍难乍易，微热，有燥屎也，承气汤。潮热，大便泄，小便不利，柴苓汤。风湿，自汗，身重，小便不利，甘草附子汤。热郁不通，田螺捣(石卜)硝，少加麝，贴脐上。寒郁不通，炒盐熨脐下。
    　　　　　伤寒小便数

    　　小便数，频来而短少也。太阳汗吐后，小便数，谵语，调胃承气汤。太阳自汗，四肢拘急，心烦，微恶寒，小便数，甘草干姜汤、芍药甘草汤。[58p]

    Injury from Cold: Difficulty in Urination

    After sweating and purging, if urination is difficult, and there is heart discomfort, use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction. After sweating in the Taiyang stage, if the pulse is floating, urination is difficult, there is slight heat and thirst, use Wu Ling San. If there is yellowing of the body, difficulty in urination, and slight abdominal fullness, use Yin Chen Hao Tang. If urination is difficult, with alternating constipation and diarrhea, slight heat, and dry stools, use Cheng Qi Decoction. If there is tidal fever, diarrhea, and difficulty in urination, use Chai Ling Tang. In cases of wind-dampness with spontaneous sweating, a heavy body, and difficulty in urination, use Gan Cao Fu Zi Tang. If there is heat blocking the flow, pound field snails (or stone calcium carbonate) and add a small amount of musk, applying it to the navel. If there is cold blocking the flow, use roasted salt to heat and apply to the area below the navel.

    Injury from Cold: Frequent Urination

    Frequent urination means the urination is short in quantity and occurs frequently. After sweating and vomiting in the Taiyang stage, if urination is frequent, with delirium, use Tiao Wei Cheng Qi Decoction. If there is spontaneous sweating in the Taiyang stage, along with stiffness in the limbs, heart discomfort, slight aversion to cold, and frequent urination, use Gan Cao Gan Jiang Tang or Shao Yao Gan Cao Tang.[58p]

    　　　　薛己医案 【明　薛己】

    　　　　　小便证治

    　　经曰：膀胱不约为遗溺，小便不禁，常常出而不觉也。人之溲溺，赖心肾二气之所传送，盖心与小肠为表里，肾与膀胱为表里。若心肾气亏，传送失道，故有此证。治宜温暖下元，清心寡欲。又有产育不顺，致伤膀胱。若内虚寒者，秘元丹、韭子丸之类。若内虚湿热者，六味地黄丸，或加五味、杜仲、补骨脂。年老者，八味丸。产育收生不谨，损破尿胞者，参朮补胞汤，如猪羊胞煎之。窃谓肝主小便，若肝经血虚，用四物、山栀。若小便濇滞，或茎中作痛，属肝经湿热，用龙胆泻肝汤。若小便频数，或劳而益甚，属脾气虚，用补中益气汤加山药、五味。若小便无度，或淋沥不禁，乃阴挺痿痹也，用六味地黄丸。若小便濇滞，或补而益甚，乃膀胱热结也，用五淋散。其脾肺燥不能化生者，黄芩清肺饮。膀胱阴虚，阳无所生者，滋肾丸。膀胱阳虚，阴无所化者，六味丸。[59p]

    Xue Ji's Medical Case Study - Ming Dynasty

    Diagnosis and Treatment of Urination Disorders

    The classics state: When the bladder is not firmly controlled, it leads to incontinence; urination occurs frequently and without awareness. The process of urination relies on the transmission of energy from both the heart and kidneys. Essentially, the heart is paired with the small intestine, while the kidneys are paired with the bladder. If the energies of the heart and kidneys are depleted, the transmission becomes obstructed, resulting in this condition.

    The treatment should focus on warming the lower yang, clearing the heart, and minimizing desires. Additionally, complications from childbirth may injure the bladder. For those with internal cold deficiency, prescriptions like Xiyuan Dan or Jiuzi Wan should be considered. For those with internal damp-heat deficiency, Liuw Wei Di Huang Wan, possibly supplemented with Wuwei, Du Zhong, or Bu Guo Zhi, is recommended. The elderly may use a formula involving Ba Wei Wan. For those with issues arising from improper childbirth or loss of support to the bladder, a medicinal concoction like Shen Zhu Bu Bao Tang should be prepared, akin to the recipe for pig or sheep bladders.

    I opine that the liver governs urination; if there is blood deficiency in the liver, one should use formulas like Si Wu and Shan Zhi. Should there be urination difficulties or pain in the urethra, likely due to liver damp-heat, Long Dan Xie Gan Tang is indicated. If urination is frequent and worsens with effort, it is attributed to spleen Qi deficiency; in this case, Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang with added Shan Yao and Wuwei is beneficial.

    If there is a lack of control over urination or persistent dripping, it may indicate a deficiency in Yin, for which Liuw Wei Di Huang Wan would be appropriate. If urinary flow is obstructed and supplementation exacerbates the condition, this points to heat accumulation in the bladder, which can be treated with Wu Lin San. If the spleen and lungs are too dry to sustain the body, Huang Qin Qing Fei Yin can help. For bladder Yin deficiency and lack of yang generation, Zi Shen Wan should be used. For bladder Yang deficiency and lack of transformation of Yin, Liuw Wei Wan is indicated.[59p]

    若阴痿思色，精不出，茎道濇痛如淋，或加减八味丸料，加车前、牛膝。若老人精竭复耗，大小便牵痛如淋，亦用前药；不应，急加附子，多有生者。　　肝火不能约制，而小便自遗或不利证，若服燥剂而频数或不利，用四物、麦门、五味、甘草。若数而黄，用四物加山茱萸、黄蘗、知母、五味、麦门。若脾虚而短少，用补中益气加山药、麦门。若阴挺痿痹而频数，用地黄丸。若热结膀胱而不利，用五苓散。若脾肺燥不能化生，用黄芩清肺饮。[60p]

    If one experiences impotence and desire but cannot produce semen, with pain in the penis like strangulation, one should add Chuanqian and Niuxi to the basic formula of the Eight Ingredients pill. If an elderly person suffers from exhaustion and has painful urination resembling strangulation, the same prescription should be applied; if it does not respond, urgently add Fuzi, as many can still recover.

    If the liver fire cannot be restrained and there is involuntary urination or painful urination, and if one takes drying agents that result in frequent or painful urination, use the Four Substances formula, along with wheat and the Five Flavors herb and licorice. If the urination is frequent and yellow, add Shan Zhuyu, Huangbai, Zhimu to the Four Substances formula, along with the Five Flavors and wheat.

    If there is deficiency of the spleen and insufficient production, use the Supplementing the Middle and Benefiting Qi formula with Shan Yao and wheat. If there is weakness and frequent urination, use the Dihuang pill. If there is heat obstructing the bladder leading to painful urination, apply the Wuling powder. If the spleen and lungs are dry and unable to nourish, use the Huangqin Qingfei drink to clear the lungs.[60p]

    若膀胱阴虚，阳无以生而淋沥，用滋肾丸。若膀胱阳虚，阴无以化而淋濇，用六味丸。若转筋小便不通，或喘急欲死，不问男女孕妇急用八味丸，缓则不救。若老人阴痿思色，精不出而内败，小便道濇痛如淋，用加减八味丸料加车前、牛膝。若老人精已竭而复耗之，大小便道牵痛，愈痛愈欲便，愈便则愈痛，亦治以前药；不应，急加附子。若喘嗽吐痰，腿足冷肿，腰骨大痛，面目浮肿，太阳作痛，亦治以前药。若痛愈而小便仍濇，宜用加减八味以缓治之。[61p]

    If the bladder is deficient in yin, resulting in an inability to generate yang and causing dripping urination, use the Kidney Nourishing Pills. If the bladder is deficient in yang, resulting in an inability to transform and causing turbid urination, use the Six-Flavor Pill. If there is cramping and difficulty with urination, or urgent dyspnea as if about to die, regardless of gender or pregnancy, urgently use the Eight-Flavor Pill; delaying will mean no relief. If an elderly man experiences impotence and desires sexual activity, yet is unable to ejaculate and suffers from internal decline, with painful and turbid urination, incorporate additional herbs in the modified Eight-Flavor Pill, such as Plantago and Achyranthes. If an elderly person has completely depleted their essence and is continuously consuming it, experiencing pulling pain in both urination and defecation—where the pain worsens with the urge to pass and the urge to pass worsens the pain—also treat with the previous medicine; if ineffective, promptly add Aconite. If there is wheezing, cough with phlegm, cold swelling in the legs and feet, severe pain in the waist and bones, and facial swelling, along with pain in the sun region, also use the previous medicine. If the pain improves but urination remains turbid, it is advisable to use the modified Eight-Flavor Pill for gentle treatment.[61p]

    大小便门

    　　　　医贯 【明　赵献可】

    　　　　　大便不通

    　　肾虚后重者，数至圊而不能便，必茎中痛，或大便不能得而小便先行而濇，或欲小便而大便反欲去而痛。独褚氏《精血论》中云：精已耗而复竭之，则大小便道牵痛，愈痛则愈便，愈便则愈痛。须以补中益气汤倍升麻送四神丸；又以八味地黄丸料加五味、吴茱萸、补骨脂、肉豆蔻，多服乃效。此等证候，以利药致损元气，肢体肿胀而毙者，不可枚举。肾既主大小便而司开阖，故大小便失职者责之肾。即此推之然，则大便不通者，独非肾乎？金匮真言论云：北方黑色，入通于肾，开窍于二阴。[62p]

    Comprehensive Collection of Ancient and Modern Books, Volume 265

    On the Gates of Urination and Defecation

    Medical Canon by Zhao Xianke (Ming Dynasty)

    Constipation

    If the kidneys are deficient and there is a sensation of heaviness in the lower body, one may feel the urge to defecate multiple times without being able to do so, often accompanied by painful sensations in the urethra. There may be instances where one is able to urinate but struggles with defecation, feeling pain instead. The treatise by Zhu’s "Theory of Essence and Blood" states that when essence is depleted and further exhausted, it can lead to pain in the pathways of urination and defecation; the more painful it is, the more the urge to defecate increases, and the more one attempts to defecate, the more pain ensues. It is necessary to administer a modified “Bou Zhong Yi Qi Decoction” with a doubled dose of Sheng Ma along with “Si Shen Wan”. Additionally, using “Ba Wei Di Huang Wan” while adding Wu Wei Zi, Wu Zhu Yu, Bu Gu Zhi, and Rou Dou Kou, with frequent consumption, will also yield effects. Such symptoms arise from laxatives damaging the vital energy, resulting in bodily swelling and lethargy, which is beyond count. Since the kidneys govern urination and defecation, failure in these functions is attributed to kidney issues. Therefore, can it be denied that constipation is not linked to the kidneys? The “True Words of the Golden Coffer” states: The black color of the northern direction pertains to the kidneys, opening the orifices of the two lower yin.[62p]

    故肾气虚，则大小便难，宜以地黄、苁蓉、车前子、茯苓之属补其阴，利水道；少佐辛药，开腠理，致津液而润其燥。洁古云：脏腑之秘，不可一概治疗，有热秘，有冷秘，有实秘，有虚秘，有风秘，有气秘，老人与产后及发汗利小便过多，病后气血未复者，皆能成秘，禁用硝、黄、巴豆、牵牛等药。世人但知热秘，不知冷秘。冷秘者，冷气横于肠胃，凝阴固结，津液不通，胃气闭塞，其人肠内气攻，喜热恶冷。宜以八味地黄丸料大剂煎之，冷饮即愈；或局方半硫丸，碾生姜调乳香下之；或海藏已寒丸，俱效。海藏云：已寒丸虽热，得芍药、茴香润剂引而下之，阴得阳而化，故大小便自通。如遇春和之阳，冰自消矣。[63p]

    Therefore, when kidney qi is deficient, urination becomes difficult. It is advisable to supplement yin and promote the water pathways with herbs such as Rehmannia, Cistanche, Plantago seeds, and Poria. Additionally, one should use some warming herbs to open up the pores, facilitate the production of bodily fluids, and moisten dryness. The ancients stated: the secrets of the organs cannot be treated uniformly; there are heat disorders, cold disorders, excess disorders, deficiency disorders, wind disorders, and qi disorders. Elderly individuals, postpartum women, and those who have sweated excessively causing frequent urination, or those unwell whose qi and blood have not yet recovered can all develop restraint, and should avoid medicines such as sodium nitrate, yellow sulfur, bovine beans, and morning glory seeds. People commonly recognize heat disorders but are ignorant of cold disorders. Cold disorders arise when cold energy obstructs the intestines and stomach, congealing yin and causing bodily fluids to stagnate, resulting in blocked stomach qi. Such individuals experience excessive internal gas and prefer warmth over cold. It is recommended to brew a large dose of Ba Wei Di Huang Wan; cold beverages will help. Alternatively, one can use the prescribed Half Sulfur Pills, crushed with fresh ginger and mixed with frankincense for ingestion; or the cold-reducing Hai Zang Pills, all of which are effective. Hai Zang also notes: although the cold-reducing pills are hot, they are guided downward by the moisture of peony and fennel, allowing the yin to receive the yang and thus facilitating urination. When the warmth of spring is encountered, the ice will naturally melt.[63p]

    然不若八味丸更妙也。东垣云：肾主五液，津液盛则大便如常，若饥饱劳役，损伤胃气，及辛热厚味，而助火邪伏于血中，耗散真阴，津液亏少，故大肠结燥。又有老年气虚，津液衰少而结者，肾恶燥急食辛以润之是也。予尝法体东垣之论，不用东垣之方，如润肠丸、润燥汤、通幽散之类俱不用，惟用六味地黄丸料，煎服自愈。如热秘而又兼气虚者，以前汤内加参、芪各五钱，立愈。此因气虚不能推送，阴虚不能濡润故耳。已上治法，予尝亲试而必验，且又不犯大黄、桃仁、枳壳等破气破血之禁，可以久服永无秘结，故表而出之。[64p]

    However, it is even more wonderful than the Eight-Flavored Pill. Dongyuan states: the kidneys govern the five fluids; when the fluids are abundant, the bowel movements are normal. If one experiences hunger, satiety, or excessive labor, it can damage the stomach's energy. Additionally, consuming spicy, hot, and rich flavors may cause fire evils to lurk in the blood, depleting the true yin and leading to deficiency of fluids, resulting in dry constipation of the large intestine. Furthermore, in the elderly with qi deficiency, when fluids are diminished, there can also be constipation. The kidneys dislike dryness and urgently require spicy substances to moisten them. I have followed Dongyuan's theories without using Dongyuan's prescriptions, avoiding pills and decoctions like the Moistening Intestines Pill, Moistening Dryness Decoction, and Unblocking the Ghost Dispersion. Instead, I utilized the Six-Flavored Rehmannia Pill, brewed and taken, which led to healing. In cases of heat-induced constipation combined with qi deficiency, adding five qian each of ginseng and astragalus to the previous decoction results in immediate recovery. This is because the qi deficiency cannot promote movement, and the yin deficiency cannot moisten. The above treatment methods have been personally tested and proven effective, avoiding the use of substances that break qi and blood, such as rhubarb, peach kernel, and bitter orange, allowing for long-term use without causing constipation. Therefore, I present this information.[64p]

    或问曰：何为不用四物汤？曰：四物汤特能补血耳。此是先天津液不足，故便难。经曰：大肠主津，小肠主液。又曰：肾主五液。津液皆肾水所化，与血何干？故不用四物汤。或又问曰：如干结之甚，硝、黄亦可暂用否？曰：承气汤用硝、黄，乃为伤寒从表入里，寒变为热，热入三阴，恐肾干枯故用硝、黄，以逐去外邪，急救肾水。余独禁用者，乃是论老人、虚人及病后人，肾水原不足以致干枯，若再用硝、黄等药以下之，是虚其虚，虽取一时之快，后必愈结。再下之后，日虽铁石亦不能通矣。倘有患此者，当劝慰之。勿令性急，自取危殆。况老人后门固者寿考之征，自是常事。若以六味八味常服，永保无虞。[65p]

    Someone asked: Why not use the Four Substance Decoction? The answer: The Four Substance Decoction is especially effective for replenishing blood. However, if there is insufficient Tianjin fluid, it becomes difficult to use. The classics state: the large intestine governs fluids, the small intestine governs liquids. Furthermore, it is said: the kidneys control the five liquids. All fluids are transformed from the kidney water; how are they related to blood? Hence, the Four Substance Decoction is not used.

    Another asked: In cases of severe dryness and constipation, can salts or sulfur be temporarily used? The answer: The Chengqi Decoction uses salts and sulfur specifically for instances where a cold has moved from the exterior to the interior, transforming into heat, and this heat enters the three yin, fearing that the kidneys may become dehydrated; therefore salts and sulfur are used to expel the external pathogen and quickly restore kidney water.

    I alone prohibit their use for the elderly, those who are deficient, and those recovering from illness, as the kidney water is originally insufficient to lead to dehydration. If one were to further use salts and sulfur and similar medicines, it would multiply their deficiency; although it may provide immediate relief, it will ultimately worsen the condition. After repeated use, even iron stones may not bring about a resolution. If anyone suffers from this, they should be comforted and not allowed to act hastily, putting themselves in danger. Moreover, for the elderly, having a firm exit is a sign of longevity, which is common. If one takes the Six-Flavors or Eight-Flavors regularly, they can maintain peace without concerns.[65p]

    　　　　　小便不通并不禁论

    　　溲溺不通，匪细故也。小腹急痛，状如覆碗，奔迫难禁，期朝不通，便令人呕，名曰关格。又日不通而毙矣。今人一见此证，却用五苓散之外，束手待毙。若盐熨丹田，蝼蛄、田螺罨脐之法，抑末也。若津液偏渗于肠胃，大便泄泻，而小便不通者，宜五苓分利之。若水停心下，不能下输膀胱者，亦用五苓渗泄之。若六腑客热，转于下焦而不通者，用益元散以清之。若气迫闭塞，升降不通者，宜升麻以提之，或探吐之。譬如水注之气，上窍开而下窍通也。[66p]

    Urinary Obstruction Should Not Be Taken Lightly

    When urination is obstructed, it is not a trivial matter. If there is urgent pain in the lower abdomen, resembling an overturned bowl, with an overwhelming urge that cannot be suppressed, and if one has not urinated by morning, it can lead to vomiting, a condition known as "Guan Ge." If the condition persists, it may even lead to death. Nowadays, when people encounter this syndrome, they resort only to Wu Ling San and end up helpless. If one applies salt to the lower abdomen or uses methods involving mole crickets or snails on the navel, that is merely a superficial remedy. If bodily fluids are excessively absorbed in the intestines and stomach, causing diarrhea while urination is obstructed, then Wu Ling San should be used to promote urination. If water is stagnant below the heart and cannot reach the bladder, Wu Ling San should also be employed to induce drainage. If the six bowels are overheated and this heat transfers to the lower jiao causing obstruction, then Yi Yuan San should be used to clear it. If energy is pressing and causing blockage, preventing normal rising and falling, one should use Sheng Ma to lift it or induce vomiting. This is similar to how water flows: if the upper orifices are open, the lower orifices will also be unobstructed.[66p]

    　　经曰：膀胱者，州都之官，津液藏焉，气化则能出矣。又曰：三焦者，决渎之官，水液出焉。可见膀胱但能藏水，必待三焦之气化，方能出水。有服附子热药太过，消尽肺阴，气所不化，用黄连解毒而通者；有用茯苓、陈皮、甘草汤送下木香、沉香末而通者，此皆气化之验也。已上治法，皆有余之证，谓膀胱中原有水，或为热结，或气闭有水可通而通之也。至于不通之证，乃虚劳汗多，五内枯燥，脂腴既去，不能生津，膀胱中原无水积而欲通之，如向乞人而求食，已穷而益穷矣。[67p]

    The classics say: The bladder is the official of the capital region, where fluids are stored, and when the qi transforms, it can discharge. Furthermore, it says: The Sanjiao is the official of the waterways, from which fluids emerge. It is clear that the bladder can only store water; it must rely on the transformation of qi in the Sanjiao to be able to discharge water. There are cases where one has taken excessive hot herbs like prepared aconite, which depletes lung yin, causing qi not to transform; using Huanglian to detoxify and open up works in this case. There are also instances of using Poria, Chenpi, and licorice decoction to deliver powdered musk and agarwood, which also demonstrates the transformation of qi. The treatment methods above are all based on excess conditions, indicating that there is already water in the bladder; whether due to heat accumulation or qi obstruction, there is water that can be opened and discharged. In contrast, the condition of inability to discharge is associated with deficiency and excessive sweating, leading to dryness within the five organs, where fatty resources are already depleted, unable to generate fluids. In such cases, there is originally no water accumulation in the bladder, and trying to open it is akin to begging for food from someone impoverished; one who is in want will only become more destitute.[67p]

    故东垣分在气在血而治之，以渴与不渴辨之。如渴而小便不利，此属上焦气分。水生于金，肺热则是清化之源绝矣。当于肺之分，助其秋令，水自生焉。如天令至秋，白露降，须用清金之药，如生脉散之类为当。又有肺虚者，盖因饮食失节，伤其胃气，陷于下焦。经所谓脾胃一虚，令人九窍不通。用补中益气汤，以参、芪甘温之品先调其胃气，以升、柴从九原之下而提之，则清升而浊自降矣。清肺者隔二之治也。补脾者，隔三之治也。东垣虚则补母之妙用类如此。[68p]

    Therefore, the East Garden divides treatment based on qi in the blood, distinguishing it by thirst or lack thereof. If there is thirst but difficulty in urination, this belongs to the upper jiao's qi division. Water arises from metal; if the lungs are hot, then the source of purification is cut off. One should assist the lungs during autumn, allowing water to arise naturally. When autumn arrives and white dew falls, one must use clear metal medicines, such as Sheng Mai San. Additionally, in cases of lung deficiency, this is typically due to irregular diet that damages stomach qi and leads to a deficiency in the lower jiao. As the scriptures say, if the spleen and stomach are both deficient, the nine orifices will be obstructed. One can use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang to replenish, using warm herbs like ginseng and astragalus to first regulate the stomach qi, allowing the rising and circulating energies to elevate the clear and lower the turbid. Clearing the lungs is treatment that is two steps removed; replenishing the spleen is treatment that is three steps removed. Thus, the essence of the East Garden's replenishment for deficiency resembles this.[68p]

    此皆滋后天之化源者，如不渴而小便不利，此属下焦血分。下焦者，肾与膀胱也，乃阴中之阴，阴受热闭，塞其下流。经曰：无阳则阴无以生，无阴则阳无以化。若淡渗之药，乃阳中之阴，非纯阴之剂，阳何以化？须用滋肾丸，此气味俱阴，乃阴中之阴也。东垣先生治一人目睛突出，腹胀如鼓，膝已上坚硬，皮肤欲裂，饮食不下，便秘危急者，精思半夜而得之，投之即愈。此是阴虚阳无以化也。盖至于真阳真阴虚者，东垣未之论。如有真阴虚者，惟六味地黄丸以补肾水，滋肾丸又所当禁，黄蘗、知母恐其苦寒泄水。[69p]

    This discusses the sources of transformation in the post-natal. If one is not thirsty but experiences difficulty in urination, this pertains to the lower body and blood. The lower body consists of the kidneys and the bladder; it is the deepest part of Yin. When Yin is heated and obstructed, it blocks its outflow. The scripture says: without Yang, Yin cannot generate; without Yin, Yang cannot transform. If one uses a medicine that is slightly penetrating, it is Yin within Yang, not a purely Yin remedy; how can Yang transform? It is necessary to use the Nourishing Kidney Pill, which has both essence and flavor of Yin, the deepest aspect of Yin.

    Dr. Dongyuan treated a patient whose eyes were bulging, abdomen distended like a drum, hardness above the knees, skin on the verge of cracking, unable to eat, and suffering from constipation in a life-threatening state.     又忌淡味渗泄之药。有真阳虚者，须八味丸。褚氏云：阴已萎而思色以降其精，则精不出而内败，小便道濇如淋，精已耗而复竭之，则大小便道牵痛，愈痛则愈便，愈便则愈痛。戴氏云：有似淋非淋，便中有如鼻涕之状，此乃精溺俱出，精塞溺道，故欲出不能而痛，宜大菟丝子丸、鹿茸丸。戴氏亦得褚氏之法也。若至于转筋，喘急欲死，不问男女孕妇产后，急用八味丸料煎饮，缓则不救。[70p]

    Avoid using medicines with mild flavors that cause leakage. For those with true Yang deficiency, one must take the Eight Flavor Pill. Zhu states: When Yin has withered and one seeks to reduce the essence, the essence does not flow out and deteriorates internally. The urinary passage becomes thick like a drip; when the essence is depleted and further exhausted, there is pain along the urinary and defecation paths. The more pain, the more frequent the urge to urinate; the more one urinates, the more pain occurs.     或疑桂附辛热，不敢轻用，岂知肾气虚寒水寒冰冻之义，得热则流通，舍此更有何物能直达膀胱而使雪消春水来耶？　　丹溪治一老人，患小便不利，因服分利之药太过，遂致秘塞，点滴不出。予以其胃气下陷，用补中益气汤，一服而通。因先多用利药，损其肾气，遂致通后遗尿，一夜不止，急补其肾，然后已。凡医之治是证者，未有不用泄利之剂，谁能固其肾气之虚哉？予特表之为世戒。后若有善法丹溪者，已明知其肺虚矣，乃以补中益气汤送肾气丸，岂不上下相须，子母相益耶？《灵枢》言手太阴之别名曰列缺，其病虚则欠呿，小便遗数。[71p]

    Some may doubt the effectiveness of桂 (osmanthus) attached to the hot property of 辛 (辛 spice), not daring to use it carelessly. How could they know the meaning of kidney essence being deficient and the coldness of water freezing?     肺为上焦，通调水道，下输膀胱，肾又上连肺，故将两脏，是子母也。母虚子亦虚，自然之理。东垣云：小便遗失，肺金虚也。宜安卧养气，禁劳役，以黄芪、人参之类大补之；不愈，当责之肾。经曰：膀胱不约为遗溺。仲景云：下焦竭，则遗溺失便。又云：下焦不归则遗溲。盖下焦在膀胱上口，主分别清浊溲便，下焦不归其部，不能约制溲便，故遗溺。大抵天暖衣厚则多汗，天冷衣薄则多溺。多溺者寒也。至于不禁，虚寒之甚，非八味丸不效。古方如菟丝子丸、鹿茸丸、二气丹，俱可选用。[72p]

    The lungs belong to the upper jiao, regulating the pathways of water, and descending to the bladder. The kidneys are also connected to the lungs, making the two organs a mother and child relationship. When the mother is deficient, the child is also deficient; this is the principle of nature. Dongyuan states: if there is a loss of urination, it is due to a deficiency of lung metal. It is advisable to rest and nurture the qi, avoiding labor, and to take tonics such as astragalus and ginseng; if there is no improvement, one must then consider the kidneys. The classics say: if the bladder is not controlled, it leads to involuntary urination. Zhongjing notes: when the lower jiao is exhausted, there will be loss of urination and bowel control. Additionally, if the lower jiao does not return, there will be involuntary urination. The lower jiao is at the opening of the bladder, responsible for distinguishing clear and turbid urine and stool; if it does not return to its area, it cannot control urination, resulting in involuntary urination. Generally, in warm weather, wearing thicker clothes leads to more sweating, whereas in cold weather, wearing lighter clothes leads to more urination. Increased urination is due to cold. For those who cannot control it, and if there is severe deficiency and cold, only the Eight-Flavored Pill will be effective. Ancient formulas such as the Cuscuta Seed Pill, Deer Antler Pill, and the Two-Qi Elixir can all be selected for use.[72p]

    戴氏云：睡着遗尿者，此亦下元冷，小便无禁而然，宜大菟丝子丸，猪胞炙碎煎汤下。凡遗尿皆属虚，刘河间谓热甚客于肾部，干于足厥阴之经，廷孔郁结甚，而气血不能宣通则痿痹，神无所用，故津液渗入膀胱，而溲溺遗失，不能收禁也。即《内经》淫气遗溺，痹聚在肾，此系热证，不可不知。考之《薛案》有因劳发热作渴，小便自遗，或时闭濇，余作肝火血虚，阴挺不能约制。午前，补中益气汤加山药、山茱萸；午后，六味丸，月余悉退。　　大抵不禁之病，虚火多而实热少，倘以虚证误投泻火，顷刻危殆，慎之。[73p]

    Dai said: "For those who wet the bed while sleeping, this is also due to cold in the lower origin.
