    大小便门

    　　　　针灸

    　　《素问》曰：刺阴股下三寸内陷，令人遗溺。　　《灵枢》曰：三焦者，足少阳太阴之所将，太阳之别也。上踝五寸，别入贯腨肠，出于委阳，并太阳之正，入络膀胱，约下焦，实则闭癃，虚则遗溺。遗溺则补之，闭癃则泻之。　　厥气走喉而不能言，手足清，大便不利，取足少阴。　　厥而腹向向然，多寒气，腹中(疒水)(疒水)[(疒水)(疒水)：原作「谷谷」，据《灵枢》杂病改。]，便溲难，取足太阴。　　手太阴之别，名曰列缺，起于腕上分间，并太阴之经，直入掌中，散入于鱼际。其病实则手锐掌热，虚则欠(去欠)，小便遗数。取之去腕半寸，别走阳明也。[146p]

    Collection of Medical Works from Ancient to Modern Times, Volume 267

    Gate of Urination and Defecation

    Acupuncture and Moxibustion

    The "Suwen" states: Needling the area three inches below the inner thigh leads to involuntary urination. The "Lingshu" states: The Sanjiao (Three Burners) is where the lesser yang and the greater yin of the foot converge; it is distinct from Taiyang (Greater Yang). Five inches above the ankle, it separates into the intestines, exits at Weiyang, and enters the bladder, connecting to the lower jiao. If it is full, it causes urinary retention; if it is deficient, it results in involuntary urination. For involuntary urination, tonify; for urinary retention, drain.

    When Qi collapses and affects the throat, causing inability to speak, with clear hands and feet, and difficult defecation, one should target the foot's lesser yin. When there is absence of Qi but the abdomen feels heavy, with internal coldness and difficulty in urination and defecation, target the foot's greater yin.

    The channel of the hand's greater yin, known as Lieque, begins at the wrist and travels along the greater yin channel, directly entering the palm, dispersing into the area between the fingers. In cases of excess, there is sharp pain and heat in the palm; in deficiency, there is frequent involuntary urination. Needle half an inch from the wrist to follow the pathway of Yangming (Greater Yang).[146p]

    　　足少阴之别，名曰大锺，当踝后繞跟，别走太阳；其别者，并经上走于心包下，外贯腰脊。其病气逆则烦闷，实则闭癃，虚则腰痛。取之所别也。　　小腹痛肿，不得小便，邪在三焦约，取之太阳大络，视其络脉，与厥阴小络结而血者。肿上及胃脘，取三里。　　癃，取之阴蹺及三毛上，及血络出血。　　大小便不利，治其标；大小便利，治其本。　　先大小便不利，而后生他病者，治其本也。　　中气不足，溲便为之变，肠为之苦鸣，补足外踝下，留之。　　《甲乙经》曰：三焦病者，腹胀气满，少腹尤甚坚，不得小便，窘急，溢则为水，留则为胀，候在足太阳之外大络，络在太阳少阳之间，亦见于脉，取委中。　　少腹满大，上走胸至心，索索然，身时寒热，小便不利，取足厥阴。　　胞转不得溺，少腹满，关元主之。[147p]

    The foot Shaoyin channel is known as the Great Clock. It winds around the heel behind the ankle and branches off to the Taiyang; its branches run above, traveling under the Heart Protector, and outward connect to the spine. When there is rebellious qi, it causes irritation; when full, it leads to urinary retention, while in deficiency, it results in low back pain. The points to be used are at the branches.

    For lower abdominal pain and swelling with difficulty urinating, if the obstruction is in the Sanjiao, use the Taiyang Great Luo point. Observe its connecting vessels and the blood with the Jueyin small vessels. If the swelling ascends to the stomach area, use the point at Sanli.

    For urinary retention, use Yin Qiao and San Mao above, along with points for blood vessels that are bleeding.

    For abnormal urination and defecation, treat the symptoms; if there is normal urination and defecation, treat the root cause.

    If there’s first difficulty in urination and then other diseases arise, treat the root.

    With insufficient central qi, urination and defecation are affected, and the intestines make uncomfortable sounds. Restore sufficient energy below the outer ankle and retain the treatment there.

    The "Jia Yi Jing" states that in cases of Sanjiao diseases, the abdomen is bloated and full of qi, especially the lower abdomen is hard, with difficulty in urination and urgency; if there is overflow, it leads to water retention, and if retained, it leads to bloating. The point to observe is outside the foot Taiyang's Great Luo, located between Taiyang and Shaoyang, and can also be felt in the pulse; use the Weizhong point.

    If the lower abdomen is full and painful, it ascends to the chest reaching the heart, causing a feeling of discomfort and oscillation, accompanied by fluctuating cold and heat, and difficulty in urination; use the foot Jueyin point.

    If the bladder cannot expel urine and the lower abdomen is full, it is governed by the Guanyuan point.[147p]

    　　小便难，水胀满，出少，胞转不得溺，曲骨主之。　　少腹胀急，小便不利，厥气上头巅，漏谷主之。　　溺难痛，白浊，卒疝，少腹肿，咳逆呕吐，卒阴跳，腰痛不可以俯仰，面黑，热，腹中(月真)满，身热厥痛，行间主之。　　少腹中满，热闭不能溺，足五里主之。　　少腹中满，小便不利，涌泉主之。[148p]

    Difficult urination, fullness of water, little output, inability to pass urine, governed by the bending bone.

    Acute fullness in the lower abdomen, ineffective urination, and qi counterflow to the head, governed by the leaking valley.

    Difficult and painful urination, turbid white discharge, sudden hernia, swelling in the lower abdomen, cough and vomiting, sudden contraction of the yin, lower back pain that limits movement, dark complexion, heat, fullness in the abdomen, body heat and pain in the extremities, governed by the space between the tendons.

    Fullness in the lower abdomen, heat causing inability to urinate, governed by the five miles.

    Fullness in the lower abdomen, ineffective urination, governed by the spring of the surge.[148p]

    　　筋急身热，少腹坚肿，时满，小便难，尻股寒，髀枢痛，引季胁，内控，八髎、委中主之。　　阴胞有寒，小便不利，承扶主之。
    　　内闭不得溲，刺足少阴太阳与骶上以长针。气逆，取其太阴阳明。　　三焦约，大小便不通，水道主之。
    　　大便难，中渚及太白主之。
    　　大便难，大锺主之。
    　　阴跳遗溺，小便难而痛，阴上下入腹中，寒疝，阴挺出偏大肿，腹脐痛，腹中悒悒不乐，大敦主之。　　遗溺，关门及神门、委中主之。
    　　胸满膨膨然，实则癃闭，腋下肿，虚则遗溺，脚急兢兢然，筋急痛，不得大小便，腰痛引腹不得俯仰，委阳主之。　　气癃，小便黄，气满，虚则遗溺，石门主之。　　癃遗溺，鼠鼷痛，小便难而白，期门主之。　　小便难，窍中热，实则腹皮痛，虚则痒搔，会阴主之。　　小肠有热，溺赤黄，中脘主之。[149p]

    When the muscles are tense and the body feels hot, the lower abdomen is firm and swollen, often feeling full, urination is difficult, and the buttocks and thighs feel cold, with pain in the hip joint radiating to the side, there is internal blockage, treated by the eight acupoints and Weizhong.

    If there is cold in the yin, urination is not smooth, treated by Chengfu.

    For internal blockage preventing urination, needle the foot's lesser yin and the sun above the sacrum with a long needle. If qi is reversed, address it through Taiyin and Yangming points.

    If the three burners are constricted, and bowel and bladder movements are impeded, treat with the waterway acupoint.

    For difficult bowel movements, treatment is with Zhongzhu and Taibai.

    For difficult bowel movements, Da Zhong should be treated.

    For involuntary urination with difficulty and pain, and lower abdominal cold hernias with one side swollen, abdominal pain around the navel, and discomfort in the abdomen, treat with Dadu. For involuntary urination, treat with Guanmen, Shenmen, and Weizhong.

    If the chest feels full and distended, with actual retention causing blockage and swelling under the armpits, or if it is a deficiency and leads to involuntary urination, while feet feel tense, with tight pain preventing bowel movements, and lower back pain radiating to the abdomen making it hard to bend or stretch, treat with Weiyang.

    If there is qi retention, yellow urination, and fullness with possible involuntary urination, treat with Shimen.

    For retention and involuntary urination with pain in the lower abdomen, experiencing difficult and cloudy urination, treat with Qimen.

    For difficult urination, accompanied by heat in the canal, with actual abdominal skin pain, or deficiency leading to itching, treat with Huiyin.

    For heat in the small intestine, resulting in red and yellow urination, use Zhongwan for treatment.[149p]

    　　溺黄，下廉主之。
    　　小便黄赤，完骨主之。
    　　小便黄，肠鸣相逐，上廉主之。
    　　劳瘅，小便赤难，前谷主之。
    　　《千金方》曰：大便难，灸第七椎两旁各一寸七壮；又灸承筋二穴各三壮，在腨中央陷内。　　大便不通，灸侠玉泉相去各二寸，名曰肠遗，随年壮；又灸大敦四壮，在足大指聚毛中。　　大便闭塞，气结，心坚满，灸石门百壮。　　后闭不通，灸足大都随年壮。
    　　老人小儿，大便失禁，灸两脚大指去甲一寸三壮；又灸大指奇间各三壮。　　大小便不利，欲作腹痛，灸荣卫四穴百壮。穴在背脊四面各一寸。　　腹热闭，时大小便难，腰痛连胸，灸团冈百壮，穴在小肠腧下二寸，横三间寸灸之。　　大小便不通，灸脐下一寸三壮；又灸横文百壮。　　大小便不利，灸八髎百壮。穴在腰目下三寸，侠脊相去四寸，两边各四穴，计八穴，故名八髎。　　小便不利，大便数注，灸屈骨端五十壮。[150p]

    Difficult urination with yellow and red indicates issues with the lower jiao.
    Yellow-red urination accompanied by bone weakness indicates a problem with the essence.
    If urination is yellow and there are gurgling sounds in the intestines, it points to issues with the upper jiao.
    If symptoms of fatigue arise with painful red urination, it indicates problems in the front valley.
    The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: for difficult bowel movements, moxa treatment should be applied to both sides of the seventh vertebra with seven applications each; also, apply moxa to the two Cheng Jin points with three applications each, located in the central depression of the abdomen.
    For constipation, moxa should be applied two inches apart from the Xiayu and Quanxuan points, known as "Intestinal Remnant," with applications based on the years; additionally, apply moxa to the Dadu point with four applications, located among the hairs at the tip of the big toe.
    If bowels are blocked, with qi stagnation and a feeling of fullness in the heart, moxa should be applied to the Shimen point with one hundred applications.
    If excretion is obstructed, moxa should be applied to the Dadu point based on years of application.
    For elderly and children experiencing bowel incontinence, apply moxa with three applications to the nails of the big toes, one inch from the tip; also, apply three applications to the spaces between the big toe and the second toe.
    For both bowel and bladder dysfunction with abdominal pain, apply moxa to the four Rongwei points with one hundred applications. These points are located one inch from the spine on each side.
    If there is abdominal heat with difficulties in urination and bowel movements, accompanied by lumbar pain extending to the chest, apply moxa to the Tuan Gang point with one hundred applications, located two inches below the small intestine point, across three thumb widths in size.
    For obstructed bowels and bladder, apply moxa one inch below the navel with three applications, and also apply to the Hengwen point with one hundred applications.
    For difficulties in urination and bowel movements, apply moxa to the eight sacral points with one hundred applications. This point is located three inches below the lumbar vertebrae, four inches apart from the spine, including four points on each side, totaling eight points, hence the name "Eight Sacral Points."
    For infrequent urination with numerous bowel movements, apply moxa to the end of the differential bone with fifty applications.[150p]

    　　小便不利，大便注泄，灸天枢百壮，穴在侠脐相去三寸。魂魄之舍不可针，大法在脐旁一寸，合脐相去可三寸也。　　遗尿失禁，出不自知，灸阴陵泉随年壮。　　溃溺，灸遗道，侠玉泉五寸；又灸阳陵泉；又灸足阳明，各随年壮。　　小便失禁，灸大敦七壮；又灸行间七壮。　　尿床，垂两手两髀上尽指头上有陷处，灸七壮；又灸脐下横文七壮。　　《东垣十书》曰：大便闭，背脊椎两旁相去各一寸，灸三壮；承筋灸三壮；肠绕，挟玉泉相去二寸，随年壮针灸。【书无此穴。或云非正穴也。】　　又法：石门，寸半；大都，五分。[151p]

    If urination is not smooth and there is profuse diarrhea, moxibustion should be applied at the Tian Shu point, located three inches away from the navel. The residence of the soul and spirit should not be needled; the main treatment is one inch beside the navel, which is also three inches away when combined with the navel.

    For incontinence and unknowingly passing urine, moxibustion should be performed on the Yin Ling Quan point, according to their strength in years.

    For ulcers and excess urination, moxibustion should be applied at the Yi Dao point, five inches from the Yu Quan point; also on the Yang Ling Quan point; and additionally on the Foot Yang Ming point, each according to their strength in years.

    In cases of urinary incontinence, apply moxibustion at the Da Dun point seven times; also on the Xing Jian point seven times.

    For bedwetting, drop both hands down to the thighs, pressing on the indented areas, and apply moxibustion seven times; also moxibustion horizontally under the navel for seven times.

    The "Ten Books of Dongyuan" states: for constipation, apply moxibustion three times on both sides of the spine, each one inch away; three times on the Cheng Jin point; if the intestines loop, moxibustion should be applied two inches from the Yu Quan point, using acupuncture and moxibustion according to their strength in years. [Some texts do not mention this point; some say it is not a proper point.]

    Additionally, the method includes: Shimen point, one and a half inches; Dadu point, five minutes.[151p]

    　　小便热痛，目赤，尿如血，列缺，沿皮一寸，太陵、承浆各五分。　　又法：曲骨，灸二七壮，阴阳二陵泉各二寸五分。　　遗溺失禁，阴陵泉、阳陵泉二寸半，大敦七壮。　　又方：曲骨、阴阳二陵泉各二寸半。　　《医学纲目》曰：大便秘濇，照海，五分，补二呼，泻六吸，立通；支沟，半寸，泻三吸。　　又法：照海泻之，立通；太白泻之，灸亦可。　　又法：照海半寸，灸二十壮，泻之；章门灸二七壮；太白半寸，灸五壮。已上诸穴，看虚实补泻之。虚结补则通，热结泻则通；寒结先泻后补，热结先补后泻之。　　又法：气海八分，令病人觉便三五次为度，出针时，记令人挟脐揉之；却刺三里五分，觉腹中鸣三五次即透。　　又法：取合谷。[152p]

    Frequent urination that is hot and painful, with red eyes and urine resembling blood, use the point Lieque, one inch along the skin, and Taijing and Chengjiang for five fen each.

    Another method: for Qugu, moxibustion with 27 sticks, and for Yin and Yang Lingquan, each two inches and five fen.

    For incontinence, apply Yinlingquan and Yanglingquan at two inches and five fen, with seven moxibustion sticks at Dadu.

    Another prescription: for Qugu, and the Yin and Yang Lingquan, each two inches and five fen.

    The "Medical Comprehensive Treatise" states: for constipation, use Zhaohai, five fen, supplement with two exhales, drain with six inhales for immediate results; use Zhigou, half an inch, drain with three inhales.

    Another method: for Zhaohai, drain it, for immediate results; drain Taibai as well, moxibustion is also an option.

    Another method: for Zhaohai, half an inch, apply moxibustion with 20 sticks, then drain it; for Zhangmen, moxibustion with 27 sticks; for Taibai, half an inch, moxibustion with five sticks.

    For all the above points, assess the condition to supplement or drain according to deficiency or excess. Supplement for deficiency and drain for heat; drain for cold stagnation first, then supplement, and for heat stagnation, supplement first then drain.

    Another method: at Qihai, eight fen, adjust so that the patient feels the urge to urinate three to five times, and when removing the needle, remind them to press and rub the navel; then, needle Sanli at five fen, and when a gurgling sound is felt in the abdomen three to five times, it will be effective.

    Another method: select Hegu.[152p]

    　　大便不通，并伤寒水结，取三间，沿皮向下至合谷穴，三补三泻，候腹中通，出针；承山七分泻之。　　小便不通，取阴谷、关元八分，令病人觉淋沥，三五次为度，便揉小腹；却取三阴交三分，即透阴谷。　　小便闭数不通，取阴谷一寸五分，灸之；阴陵泉泻之。又法取偏历。　　小便闭不通，取阴陵泉、阴谷、三阴交、气海、关元灸三十壮，刺二寸五分；不已，取太溪、阴交。　　小便数腹痛，取尿胞，在玉泉下一寸，屈骨端。　　小便多，灸命门，随年壮；又取肾俞一分，沿皮向外六分，补六呼，泻一吸。　　小便滑数，灸中极、肾腧、阴陵泉；不已，取气海、阴谷、三阴交。[153p]

    If there is constipation caused by water stagnation due to a cold, acupuncture should be performed three times along the skin down to the Hegu point, with three reinforcing and three reducing techniques, waiting for relief in the abdomen before removing the needle; for the Chengshan point, reduce by seven parts.

    For urinary retention, acupuncture should be done at Yingu and Guanyuan with eight parts, allowing the patient to feel a dripping sensation, repeated three to five times, and gently massage the lower abdomen; then, take Sanyinjiao for three parts, passing through Yingu.

    If there is severe urinary retention with infrequent urination, needle Yingu by one and a half inches and apply moxibustion; reduce at Yinlingquan. Additionally, consider using Pianli.

    For urinary retention without passage, needle Yinlingquan, Yingu, Sanyinjiao, Qihai, and Guanyuan with thirty moxibustion applications, inserting the needle two and a half inches deep; if it persists, needle Taixi and Yinjiao.

    If there is painful urination, needle the urinary bladder one inch below Yuquan at the tip of the bent bone.

    For excessive urination, apply moxibustion at Mingmen according to the yearly strength; also treat Shenju with one part, moving six parts outward from the skin surface, reinforce with six breaths, and reduce with one breath.

    If urination is slippery and frequent, perform moxibustion at Zhongji, Shenxu, and Yinlingquan; if it persists, needle Qihai, Yingu, and Sanyinjiao.[153p]

    　　　　导引

    　　《保生秘要》曰：大便不通导引法，以舌顶上腭，守铉雍静念而液自生，俟满口赤龙搅动，频嗽频吞，听降直下丹田，又守静咽数回，大肠自润，行后功，效。　　运功：左手抚脐，用意推旋开五脏向后，落大肠九曲行去；或升肾水，洗润大肠九曲而通泻之。　　以手覆脐，又推开五脏向后，落大肠九曲去；或升肾水，洗浴大肠九曲而泻之。　　尾闾坠气导引法：咬牙闭气，耸肩，双目圆睁，左右转动，谷道紧撮，如此行之，气自然升。　　运功：元气下陷之证，气出不臭是也。因闭气行功，不能转升故耳。当存归元法，运周天七日，见效。[154p]

    Guidance

    The "Secret Essentials of Preserving Life" states: For the method of guiding when bowel movements are not smooth, press the tongue against the roof of the mouth, maintaining calmness and silence while the fluid is generated on its own. Wait for the mouth to fill with a red dragon stirring, frequently cough and swallow, and listen as it descends directly to the elixir field. Then maintain stillness and swallow several times, and the large intestine will naturally moisten, enabling the subsequent workings to be effective.

    For the practice of moving energy: with the left hand on the navel, direct intentions to rotate and open the five organs backward, allowing the pathway of the large intestine to run smoothly; or raise the kidney water to wash and moisten the large intestine and promote expulsion. Cover the navel with the hand, again push the five organs backward to clear the pathway of the large intestine; or raise kidney water to cleanse and purge the large intestine.

    For the guiding method of the tailbone’s energy descent: clench your teeth, hold your breath, raise your shoulders, open your eyes wide, and turn your head left and right while tightly clenching the buttocks; by doing so, the energy will naturally rise.

    The practice: The sign of the primordial energy sinking is when the expelled gas does not have a foul odor. Since holding the breath during practice prevents the energy from rising, one should adhere to the method of returning to the primordial source, completing a full circuit for seven days to see results.[154p]

    有用功通尾闾及夹脊双关之后，不能招摄而坠者，宜用静功返照，自然升顶，不必执着。　　小水迟滞导引法：搓小纸捻入鼻中，俟打喷嚏，小水自通，此治闭塞。若迟塞，多搓掌心及涌泉穴，退火安静，或行运法，效。　　运功及小肠证同治，从归元法。旋运而下，旋至病处，多运数十回，复繞而上，撤而散之，周而复始，如法渐行，谷道去浊，提回守静。　　溺管泄气导引法：用指按坎穴，搓运二十四下，意从灵物顶上吸气一口，转河车周天，一九数归元，又提行三九而吐纳，兼用运功效。　　运功：此证感于坐功之人，当凝想气海半晌后，默运旋转，动中又静，念念不忘，其气自收。　　归元诀行之之法，提意出上，斡旋造化，从左而右，先运脐轮，收而放，放而复收，以还本位，不离这个，念自归真矣。[155p]

    When using effective techniques targeting the tailbone and the dual acupuncture points along the spine, if one cannot summon the energy and it falls away, it is advisable to employ quiet practices of introspection to naturally rise to the crown without attachment. The method for guiding the small water when it is stagnant involves rolling a small paper into a point and inserting it into the nose, waiting for a sneeze to clear the blockage. If stagnation persists, rub the palms and the Yongquan point, calming the fire and settling the spirit, or practice circulation techniques for effect.

    The method of circulation and the small intestine condition can be treated in the same way, following the principle of returning to the source. Rotate and move downward, then reach the affected area, moving in this manner several dozen times, then spiral upward, dispersing and surrounding it continuously, repeating the process gradually, purifying the passage and maintaining calm.

    For guide pressure on the urinary canal: press on the Kan point with a finger and perform circular motions twenty-four times, while mentally inhaling from above the spiritual center, rotating the energy around, returning to the source with each cycle, and then drawing it upward three times for breathing practice, combining the movement techniques for effect.

    With regards to the movements: those affected by seated meditation should focus their thoughts on the sea of qi for a while, then silently rotate and circulate, moving yet still, constantly mindful, allowing the energy to consolidate. The method of returning to the source involves directing the intention upward, rotating and transforming the essence from left to right, first moving the navel wheel, collecting and releasing, releasing and then collecting, returning to the original state, never departing from this, and the thoughts naturally return to their true origin.[155p]

    　　　　医案

    　　《儒门事亲》曰：戴人过曹南省亲，有姨表兄病大便燥濇，无他证，常不敢饱食，饱则大便极难，结实如铁石，或三五日一如圊，目前星飞，鼻中血出，肛门连广肠痛，痛极则发昏，服药则病转剧烈，巴豆、芫花、甘遂之类皆用之，过多则困，泻止则复燥，如此数年。遂畏药性暴急不服，但卧病待尽。戴人过，诊其两手脉息，俱滑实有力，以大承气汤下之，继服神功丸、麻仁丸等药，使食菠薐葵菜及猪牛血作羹，百余日，充肥，亲知见骇之。呜呼！粗工不知燥分四种：燥于外则皮肤皱揭，燥于中则精血枯涸，燥于上则咽鼻焦干，燥于下则便溺结闭。夫燥之为病，是阳明化也，水液寒少故如此。然可下之，当择之药。如巴豆可以下寒，甘遂、芫花可以下湿，大黄、(石卜)硝可以下燥。《内经》曰：辛以润之，咸以软之。《周礼》曰：以滑养窍。[156p]

    Medical Case

    "The Confucian Door to Filial Piety" states: A man named Dai visited his relatives in Cao Nan and found that his cousin was suffering from severe constipation. There were no other symptoms; he often dared not eat to fullness, as doing so would lead to extremely difficult bowel movements, with stools as hard as iron or stone. Sometimes, he would go three to five days without a bowel movement, and when it occurred, it was painfully difficult. Blood would come from his nose, and he experienced pain in the anus and rectum. The pain was so extreme that it would cause fainting. When he took medicine, his condition worsened. He had tried various harsh laxatives like croton seed, bitter herb, and euphorbia, but excessive use only led to exhaustion, and stopping the laxatives led to dryness returning, resulting in this suffering lasting for several years. Frightened of the violent effects of these medications, he merely lay in bed and awaited death.

    When Dai arrived, he took the pulse of both hands and found it smooth, solid, and strong. He then administered a dose of the Big Cold Purging Decoction, followed by the Divine Efficacy Pill and Hemp Seed Pill. He instructed him to eat dishes made from soft vegetables and pig or beef blood, and after over a hundred days, his weight increased significantly, shocking his relatives.

    Alas! Inexperienced practitioners fail to recognize that dryness can be categorized into four types: external dryness manifests as wrinkled skin, internal dryness leads to depletion of essence and blood, upper dryness causes dryness in the throat and nose, while lower dryness results in constipation and urination difficulties. The disease of dryness arises from the transformation of the yangming, due to a cold and scanty presence of fluid. Thus, purging is necessary, but the right medicine must be chosen. For instance, croton seed can purge cold, bitter herb and euphorbia can relieve dampness, and rhubarb along with saline can purge dryness. The "Inner Canon" states: "Use warmth to moisten," and "Use salty to soften." The "Rites of Zhou" mentions: "Use slippery substances to nourish the orifices."[156p]

    　　顷有老人年八十岁，脏腑濇滞，数日不便，每临后时，目前星飞，头目昏眩，鼻塞腰痛，积渐始减，纵得食，便结燥如弹。一日，友人命食血脏葵羹油渫菠薐菜，遂顿食之，日日不乏，前后皆利，食进神清，年九十岁，无疾而终。《图经》云：菠菜寒，利肠胃。芝麻油炒而食之，利大便。葵宽肠，利小溲。年老之人，大小便不利，最为急切，此亦偶得泻法耳。[157p]

    Recently, there was an elderly man aged eighty. His internal organs were sluggish, and he had not been able to attend to his bodily needs for several days. Each time he felt the urge, he found his spirit dimming, his head spinning, his nose blocked, and his waist in pain. Gradually, his condition worsened, and although he could eat, his stool became hard and dry like a pellet. One day, a friend recommended that he eat a soup made from blood stuffed with vegetables and oil-fried amaranth greens. He began to eat this daily, and soon he experienced relief both before and after eating. His spirit brightened with the food, and he lived to ninety years old, passing away without illness. The 'Illustrated Treatise' states: Spinach is cold and beneficial for the intestines and stomach. Sesame oil, when stir-fried and consumed, facilitates bowel movements. Amaranth relaxes the intestines and aids in urination. For elderly people, difficulties in urination and defecation are urgent matters; thus, this method of relief is indeed a fortunate find.[157p]

    　　太康刘仓使病大便少而频，日七八十次，常于两股间悬半枚壶卢，如此十余年。戴人见之而笑曰：病既频而少，欲通而不得通也，何不大下之？此通因通用也。此一服药之力。乃与药大下三十余行，顿止。
    　　《东垣十书》曰：昔长安有大贾王善夫病小便不通，渐成中满，腹大坚硬如石，壅塞之极，腿脚肿胀，破裂出黄水，双睛凸出，昼夜不得眠，饮食不下，苦痛不可名状，求予治之。因问受病之始，如病不渴，近苦呕哕，众医皆用治中满利小便淡渗之药。急难措手，乃辞归，从夜至旦，耿耿不寝，穷究其理。忽记《素问》有云：无阳则阴无以生，无阴则阳无以化。又云：膀胱者州都之官，津液藏焉，气化则能出矣。此病小便癃闭，是无阴而阳气不化者也。凡利小便之药，皆淡味渗泄为阳，止是气药，阳中之阴，非北方寒水阴中之阴所化者。[158p]

    Tai Kang Liu Cang suffered from a condition of frequent but scant bowel movements, going up to seventy or eighty times a day, and habitually suspended a small vessel between his thighs for over ten years. A bystander laughed and said, "Since your condition is frequent yet scant, desiring to relieve yourself but unable to do so, why not take a strong laxative?" This suggests that the term "relieve" encompasses more than just ease. This was the effect of a single dose of medicine. He then took a powerful laxative that caused over thirty bouts of relief, after which he immediately stopped.

    The "Eastern Garden's Ten Writings" states: In ancient Chang'an, there was a wealthy merchant named Wang Shanfu who suffered from urinary obstruction, gradually developing abdominal fullness. His belly was hard as stone, and he faced extreme blockage with swollen legs and feet that burst, leaking yellow fluid, while his eyes protruded. Day and night he could not sleep, unable to eat, suffering indescribable pain, and he sought my treatment. I inquired about the onset of his illness; he mentioned he felt no thirst and had bouts of severe vomiting. Various doctors all prescribed treatments for abdominal fullness and diuretics. Faced with an urgent situation, I returned home, and through the night until dawn, I was restless, pondering the matter deeply. Suddenly I recalled the "Suwen" stating: "Without Yang, Yin cannot thrive; without Yin, Yang cannot transform." It also states: "The bladder is the official responsible for the regions, where fluids are stored, able to expel when qi transforms." This illness of urinary retention is due to the absence of Yin, preventing the transformation of Yang energy. All diuretic medicines are light and infiltrating, representing Yang. They merely promote qi, being Yin within Yang, but not transforming from the cold Yin of northern water.[158p]

    此乃奉养太过，膏粱积热，损北方之阴，肾水不足，故膀胱、肾之室久而干涸，小便不化，火又逆上而为呕哕，非隔上所生也。独为关，非格病也。洁古老人曰：热在下焦，填塞不便。是治关格之法。今病者内关外格之病悉具，死在旦夕，但治下焦可愈。随处以禀北方寒水所化，大苦寒气味俱阴者，黄蘗、知母、桂为引用，丸如桐子大，沸汤下二百丸，服药少时，须臾前阴如刀刺火烧之痛，溺出如瀑泉涌出，卧具皆湿，床下成流，顾盼之间，肿胀消散。予惊喜曰：大哉圣人之言！岂可不遍览而执一者也！其证小便闭塞而不渴，时见躁者是也。凡诸病居下焦，皆不渴也。二者之病，在气在血，最易分别。
    　　《丹溪心法》曰：杨淳三哥大便秘濇，小便如常，咽塞不通，食下便有痰出，脉濇，左右手同，此血虚肠燥为脾约病甚者，人参散主之。
    　　一妇人脾痛后，患大小便不通，此是痰隔中焦，气滞于下焦，以二陈汤加木通，初吃后，煎柤吞之。[159p]

    This is due to excessive nourishment, with rich foods accumulating heat, damaging the Northern yin, resulting in insufficient kidney water. Consequently, the bladder and kidney chambers become dry over time, and urination is not transformed, with fire rising to cause vomiting, which is not a condition caused by obstruction above. It is specifically related to the "guan" (barrier), not a disease of obstruction. The ancient elder Jie Gu stated: with heat in the lower jiao, it fills and obstructs. This is the method for treating obstructive conditions. The patient presents with both internal and external obstructive diseases, facing imminent death, yet treating the lower jiao may lead to recovery. One should adapt to the transformation of cold water from the North, using bitter cold herbs that are entirely yin, such as Huanglian, Zhimu, and Gui, formulated into pills the size of tung seeds. Boil them in water and take two hundred pills; shortly after taking the medicine, the anterior yin will feel as if stabbed by a knife and burned with pain, the urination will gush out like a waterfall, soaking the bedding, forming streams beneath the bed, and swelling will dissipate upon careful observation. I expressed my surprise, saying: "Great are the words of the sage! How could one not thoroughly examine them and cling to but one!" The evidence shows that when urination is obstructed but there is no thirst, and there are signs of agitation, this is it. Generally, all illnesses in the lower jiao do not present with thirst. The two types of illness, concerning qi and blood, are easiest to differentiate.

    The "Danxi Heart Method" states: Yang Chun had severe constipation, with urination normal, the throat obstructed, and phlegm appearing after eating. The pulse was thin, and both hands were the same. This is a severe case of spleen qi deficiency leading to dry intestines, for which Ren Shen San is the main treatment.

    A woman experienced abdominal pain and later suffered from obstructed urination and defecation. This is phlegm blocking the middle jiao, with qi stagnation in the lower jiao. Using Erchen Decoction with Mutong, she initially took it and swallowed after decocting.[159p]

    　　吕仲年六十六岁，病伤寒得汗，热退后，脉尚洪，此洪脉作虚脉论，与人参、黄芪、白朮、炙甘草、当归、芍药、陈皮数日，其脉仍大，未收敛。又小便不通，小腹下妨闷，颇为所苦，但仰卧则点滴而出。予曰：补药服之未至。前药倍加黄芪、人参大剂与服，两日小便方利。
    　　一男子病小便不通，医用通利药而反剧。丹溪曰：此积痰也。痰积在肺，肺为上焦，膀胱为下焦，上焦闭则下焦塞，譬如滴水之器，必上窍通，而后下窍之水出焉。乃以吐法大吐之。吐已，病如失。然此可见癃淋又不独主于经病也。
    　　马希圣年五十余，性嗜酒，常痛饮，糟粕出前窍，便溺出后窍，六脉皆沉濇，与四物汤加海金沙、木香、槟榔、木通、桃仁，服而愈。此人酒多而肆气，酒升而不降，阳极虚，酒湿积久生热，煎熬血干，阴亦大虚。阴阳偏虚，皆可补接。此人中年后阴阳俱虚时暂可活者，以其形实，酒中谷气尚在。三月后，其人必死。后果然。[160p]

    Lu Zhongnian was sixty-six years old when he fell ill with a cold and fever. After the heat subsided, his pulse remained strong and rapid. This rapid pulse was analyzed as weak, and he was given a mixture of ginseng, astragalus, white atractylodes, roasted licorice, angelica, peony, and dried citrus peel for several days, but his pulse remained large and did not settle down. Additionally, he had difficulty urinating and experienced a distended sensation in his lower abdomen, which greatly troubled him; he could only manage to urinate by lying on his back. I said that the nourishing medicine had not yet reached him. I then doubled the dose of astragalus and ginseng, and after two days, his urination improved.

    A man presented with urinary obstruction, and the doctor prescribed diuretics, which worsened his condition. Danxi said: This is due to accumulated phlegm. The phlegm accumulates in the lungs, which is the upper jiao, while the bladder is the lower jiao. When the upper jiao is obstructed, the lower jiao is also blocked. This is like a dripping water vessel; both the upper and lower openings must be clear for the water to flow out. Therefore, he used a method of inducing vomiting to expel it. After vomiting, the illness seemed to be alleviated. This shows that urinary retention is not solely governed by the channels' diseases.

    Ma Xisheng, over fifty years old, had a fondness for alcohol and frequently drank heavily. The sediment would exit through the mouth, while urination occurred through the lower orifice. His six pulses were deep and sluggish. He was treated with the Four Substances Decoction, enhanced with peppermint, areca nut, peach kernel, and akebia, and he recovered. This man had excess alcohol, which harmed his vital energy; the alcohol ascended without descending, leaving his yang extremely deficient. Long-term alcohol consumption accumulated moisture and generated heat, depleting the blood and also exhausting the yin. Both yin and yang being deficient can be replenished. This man, since his middle age, could still survive when both yin and yang were temporarily weak, due to his robust build and the vitality still present in the alcohol he consumed. However, after three months, he was bound to die. Eventually, this indeed happened.[160p]

    　　一人年四十，口干溺数，春末得之，夏求治，脉俱濇，右略数而不弦，重取似大而稍有力，左稍沉，略弱而不强，然濇却多于右，喜二尺皆不甚起，当作饮食厚味生热，此谓之痰热。禁其厚味，降火以清金，抑肝而补脾，三补丸二十一粒，元明粉五粒，阿胶五粒，姜汤吞下，一日六次。又以四物汤加参、朮、陈皮、生甘草、五味、麦门冬煎服，一日三次，与丸药间服之。一二日，自觉清快，小便减三之二，口不干，止渴未消，头运眼花，久坐则腰疼，遂以摩腰丹治腰痛，仍以四物减川芎，加参、芪、白朮、牛膝、五味、炒蘗、麦门冬，煎调六一散。反觉便多，遂去六一散，仍服丸药。[161p]

    A person aged forty is experiencing dry mouth and frequent urination. At the end of spring, a remedy was sought in the summer; pulse readings indicate dryness, the right pulse is slightly rapid but not wiry, strong yet somewhat forceful, while the left is slightly heavy, a bit weak, and not strong. However, the dryness in the left pulse is more pronounced than in the right. There is a preference for warming rich foods; this is referred to as phlegm-heat.     　　一妇转胞小便闭，脉似濇，重取则弦，左稍和，此得之忧患。濇为血少气多，弦为有饮，血少则胞不举，气多有饮，中焦不清而溢，则胞知所避而就下故坠。以四物汤加参、朮、半夏、陈皮、甘草、生姜，空心饮，随以指探吐之。俟气定又与，至八贴而安。此恐偶中，后又治数人，皆效。[162p]

    A woman experiences a blockage in urination with a pulse that is thin and weak; when re-examined, it feels string-like. The left side is slightly harmonious. When the middle burner is not clear and overflows, the womb senses the need to retreat and thus descends.

    　　一老人患小便不利，因服分利之药太过，遂致闭塞，点滴不出。予以其胃气下陷，用补中益气汤，一服而通。因先多用利药，损其肾气，遂致通后遗尿，一夜不止，急补其肾，然后已。
    　　《卫生宝鉴》曰：中书右丞合刺合孙病小便数而欠，日夜约去二十余行，脐腹胀满，腰脚沉重，不得安卧。至元癸未季春下旬，予奉圣旨治之，遂往诊视。脉得沉缓，时时带数，尝记小便不利者有三，不可一概而论。若津液偏渗于肠胃，大便泄泻，而小便濇少，一也，宜分利而已；若热搏下焦，津液则热濇而不行，二也，必渗泄则愈；若脾胃气濇，不能通利水道，下输膀胱而化者，三也，可顺气令施化而出也。今右丞平居膏粱，湿热内畜，不得施化，膀胱窍濇，是以起数而见少也。非渗泄分利，则不能快利。[163p]

    遂处一方，名曰茯苓琥珀汤。《内经》曰：甘缓而淡渗。热搏津液内畜，脐胀腹满，当须缓之。缓之必以甘淡为主。是用茯苓为君。滑石甘寒滑以利窍，猪苓、琥珀之淡以渗泄而利水道，故用三味为臣。脾恶湿，湿气内畜则脾气不治，益脾胜湿，必用甘为助，故以甘草、白朮为佐。咸入肾，咸味下泄为阴，泽泻之咸，以泻伏水；肾恶燥，急食辛以润之，津液不行，以辛散之，桂枝味辛散湿润燥，此为因用，故以二物为使。煎用长流甘烂水，使不助其肾气。大作汤剂，令直达于下而急行也。两服减半，旬日良愈。[164p]

    Thus, it is prepared as a formula named Fu Ling Hu Po Decoction. The "Inner Canon" states: sweet, gentle, and mildly permeating. When heat obstructs the body’s fluids, causing abdominal distention and fullness, it must be eased. This easing must primarily rely on sweetness and mildness. Therefore, Fu Ling is used as the chief ingredient. Hua Shi is sweet, cold, and smooth, facilitating the orifices, while Zhu Ling and Hu Po are mild and help to drain and benefit the water pathways, hence these three are used as assistants. The spleen is averse to dampness; when dampness accumulates, the spleen's function cannot be restored. To augment the spleen and combat dampness, sweetness must assist; thus, Gan Cao and Bai Zhu are employed as deputies. Salty flavors enter the kidneys; the salty taste promotes drainage, and Ze Xie’s saltiness helps drain the stagnant water. The kidneys are also adverse to dryness;辛 (spicy) flavors must be consumed quickly to moisten them. When body fluids do not flow, spicy substances can disperse them. Gui Zhi is spicy and disperses dampness while moistening dryness, which is the rationale for their use; hence these two are used as messengers. Decoct long and with sweet and soft water to avoid aiding kidney energy. Prepare a significant quantity of the decoction, allowing it to reach below and act swiftly. Reduce the dosage to half for two administrations, and within ten days, significant improvement will be observed.[164p]

    　　《医学正传》曰：本邑赵德秀才之母，年五十余，身材瘦小，得大便燥结不通，饮食少进，小腹作痛。召予诊治。六脉皆沉伏而结濇，予作血虚，治用四物汤加桃仁、麻仁、煨大黄等药，数服不通，反加满闷。与东垣枳实导滞丸，及备急大黄丸等，药下咽，片时即吐出，盖胃气虚，而不能久留性速之药耳。遂以备急大黄丸，外以黄蜡包之，又以细针穿一窍，令服三丸。盖以蜡匮者，制其不犯胃气，故得出幽门，达大小肠取效也。明日，下燥屎一升许。继以四物汤加减作汤，使吞润肠丸。如此调理月余，得大便如常，饮食进而平安。[165p]

    An elderly scholar had wind-heat symptoms, maintained normal eating habits, yet had not had a bowel movement for seventeen days. I prescribed over twenty doses of the Six-flavor Pill, and it took until the thirty-second day for him to have the desire to go. I used pig bile to moisten and clear his bowels.

    A seventy-three-year-old woman suffered from phlegm, wheezing due to internal heat, and had not had a bowel movement for two months, with insomnia. Her pulse was large and strong, yet weak upon heavy palpation. This indicated a deficiency in the liver, lungs, and kidneys. In the morning, I prescribed the Six-flavor Pill, and in the evening, the Free and Easy Wanderer Powder, each for over thirty doses. After consuming a hundred or so bowls of food, her abdomen began to feel distended and uncomfortable. I then used pig bile to guide and clear her bowels, and adjusted her treatment with the Supreme Ginseng and Astragalus Combination for stabilization. If any previous medications were omitted, or if she did not eat, her symptoms would return.[171p]

    　　一男子年五十余，因怒少食，大便不利，服润肠丸，大便闭结，胸胁作痛，欲兼服脾约丸，肝脾肾脉浮而濇。余曰：此足三阴精血亏损之证也。东垣先生云：若人胃强脾弱，约束津液。不得四布，但输膀胱，小便数而大便难者，用脾约丸。若人阴血枯槁，内火燔烁，肺金受邪，土受木伤脾，肺失传，大便闭而小便数者，用润肠丸。今滋其化源，则大便自调矣。如法果验。
    　　一儒者，怀抱郁结，复因场屋不遂，发热作渴，胸膈不利，饮食少思，服清热化痰行气等剂，前证益甚，肢体倦怠，心脾二脉濇滞，此郁结伤脾之变证也。遂用加味归脾汤，饮食渐进，诸证渐退。但大便尚濇，两颧赤色，此肝肾虚火，内伤阴血，用八珍汤加苁蓉、麦冬、五味，至三十余剂，大便自润。[172p]

    A man in his fifties, due to anger, ate little and had difficulty with bowel movements. After taking a laxative pill, he experienced constipation, chest and side pain, and wished to also take a pill for strengthening the spleen. His pulse was floating and thin in the liver, spleen, and kidney. I said: This indicates a deficiency of the three yin's essence and blood. Doctor Dongyuan said: If a person has a strong stomach but a weak spleen, it restricts the bodily fluids. When they cannot be distributed throughout but instead are directed to the bladder, resulting in frequent urination and difficulty with bowel movements, use the spleen-strengthening pill. If a person has dry yin blood with inner heat burning, the lung metal suffers from evil, and the earth is injured by wood affecting the spleen, causing the lungs to lose their transmission, then if there is constipation with frequent urination, use the laxative pill. Now, nourishing the source of transformation will naturally adjust the bowel movements. Follow this method, and it will be proven effective.

    A Confucian scholar, with feelings of depression and setbacks due to an unfinished task, developed a fever and thirst, and felt discomfort in his chest and diaphragm, along with decreased appetite. He took remedies to clear heat, transform phlegm, and move qi, but his prior symptoms worsened, and he felt fatigued with stagnation in the heart and spleen pulses. This indicated a change due to spleen damage from depression. Therefore, he was given a modified Gui Pi Decoction, and gradually, his appetite improved and symptoms receded. However, his bowel movements remained sluggish, and his cheeks were flushed red, indicating deficient kidney and liver heat harming yin blood. He was treated with Ba Zhen Decoction plus epimedium, ophiopogon, and schisandra for more than thirty doses, and his bowel movements became normal.[172p]

    　　一男子所患同前，不信余言，服大黄等药，泄泻便血，遍身黑黯，复求治。余视之曰：此阴阳二络俱伤也。阳络伤则血外溢，阴络伤则血内溢。辞不治，后果然。
    　　职方陈莪斋年逾六旬，先因大便不通，服内疏等剂，后饮食少思，胸腹作胀，两胁作痛，形体倦怠，两尺浮大，左关短濇，右关弦濇。时五月请治，余意乃命门火衰，不能生脾土，而肺金又克肝木，忧其金旺之际不起。后果然。
    　　刘天锡内有湿热，大便滑利小便濇滞，服淡渗剂，愈加滴沥，小腹腿膝皆肿，两眼胀痛。此肾虚热在下焦，服淡渗导损阳气，则阴无以化。遂用地黄、滋肾二丸，小便如故；更以补中益气加麦门、五味兼服而愈。
    　　一富商，饮食起居失宜，大便干结，常服润肠等丸。后胸腹不利，饮食不甘，口干体倦，发热吐痰。服二陈、黄连之类，前证益盛，小便滴沥，大便泄泻，腹胀少食。服五苓、瞿麦之类，小便不通，体肿喘嗽。用金匮肾气丸、补中益气汤而愈。[173p]

    A man suffered similarly as before, disbelieving my words, took large doses of rhubarb and other medications, experienced diarrhea and bloody stools, and his body turned dark.     　　大司徒许函谷，在南银台时因劳发热，小便自遗，或时不利，余作肝火，阴挺不能约制。午前，用补中益气加山药、黄蘗、知母，午后服地黄丸，月余全安。
    　　司徒边华泉，小便频数，濇滞短赤，口干唾痰，此肾经阳虚热躁，阴无以化，用六味、滋肾二丸而愈。
    　　考功杨朴庵，口舌干燥，小便频数，此膀胱阳燥阴虚。先用滋肾丸以补阴而小便愈，再用补中益气、六味地黄以补肺肾而安。
    　　一儒者发热无时，饮水不绝，登厕则小便濇痛，大便牵痛，此精竭所致，用六味丸加五味，又补中益气，喜其谨守得愈。若肢体畏寒，喜热饮食，用八味丸。
    　　刘大参年逾六旬，形气瘦弱，小便不禁或频数，内热口干，或咳痰喘运。余以为肺肾气虚，用六味丸、益气汤以滋化源。彼不信，反服补阴降火濇精之剂，阴窍作痛，或小便不利。仍服前药，不两月而愈。[174p]

    　　《证治准绳》曰：甲午秋治一妇人，年五十，初患小便濇，医以八正散等剂，展转小便不通，身如芒刺加于体。予以所感霖淫雨湿，邪尚在表，因用苍朮为君、附子佐之发其表，一服即汗，小便即时便通。
    　　马参政父年八旬，初患小便短濇，因服药分利太过，遂致闭塞，涓滴不出。予以饮食太过，伤其胃气，陷于下焦，用补中益气汤，一服小便通。因先多利药，损其肾气，遂致通后遗尿一夜不止，急补其肾，然后已。凡医之治是证，未有不用泄利之剂者，安能顾其肾气之虚哉？表而出之，以为世戒。
    　　有瘀血而小便闭者，宜多用牛膝。《本事方》云：顷在毗陵有一贵官妻妾，小便不通，肚腹胀痛不可忍。众医皆作淋治，如八正散之类，数种皆治，不通，病愈甚。予诊之曰：此血瘕也，非瞑眩药不可去。乃用桃仁煎，初服至日午，大痛不可忍卧，少顷，下血块如拳者数枚，小便如黑豆汁一二升，痛止得愈。此药猛峻，气虚血弱者，宜斟酌之。[175p]

    "The Standard for Diagnosis and Treatment" states: In the autumn of the Jiawu year, I treated a woman aged fifty who initially suffered from frequent urination. The physician prescribed Ba Zheng San and similar remedies, but her urination did not improve, and she felt as if she was being pierced by thorns. I attributed it to dampness caused by excessive rain, believing that the pathogen remained on the surface. Therefore, I used Cang Zhu as the main ingredient and Fu Zi as an assistant to release it from the surface. After one dose, she sweated and her urination immediately became smooth.

    Ma Shen Zheng's father, aged eighty, initially suffered from short and frequent urination. After taking medicinal herbs, he experienced excessive urination leading to a complete blockage, with not a single drop coming out. I deduced that excessive consumption had harmed his stomach energy, causing his lower body to become deficient. I prescribed Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, and after one dose, his urination returned. Since he had previously taken too many diuretics, it had harmed his kidney energy, which caused him to experience nocturnal incontinence after correction. I urgently supplemented his kidney energy, and then the situation improved. In all medical treatments, there has never been a case where diuretic agents are not used; how could one care for the deficiency of kidney energy?

    For cases involving stagnant blood leading to urination difficulties, it is advisable to use a lot of Niu Xi. The "Ben Shi Fang" recounts that recently in Piling, the wife of a high official experienced an inability to urinate and unbearable abdominal swelling and pain. Numerous physicians treated her for dysuria with remedies like Ba Zheng San, yet her condition did not improve and worsened. Upon examination, I diagnosed it as blood stagnation, and no gentle remedies could resolve it. I then used a decoction of Tao Ren, which initially caused great pain around noon; shortly after, several blood clots the size of fists were expelled, and her urine flowed like black bean juice in one to two sheng, relieving the pain. This medicine is potent and should be used cautiously for those with weak energy and blood.[175p]

    　　《医方考》曰：宋季饶医熊彦诚，年五十五岁，病前后便溺不通，五日腹胀如鼓，同辈环视，皆不能措力。与西湖妙果僧慧月相善，遣信邀至诀别。月惊驰而往，于钓桥逢一异客，揖之曰：方外高人，何孑孑走趋若是？月曰：一善友久患秘结，病危急，欲往问。客曰：易事耳。待奉施一药。即脱靴入水，探一大螺而出。曰：事济矣。抵家，以盐半匙，和壳生捣，置病者脐下一寸三分，用宽帛紧系之，仍办溺器以须其通。月未以为然，姑巽谢之。至熊家，彦诚昏不知人，妻、子聚泣。如诸医无他策，慢使试之，曾未安席而暴下。诸医愧叹而散。月归访异人，无所见矣。熊后十六年乃终。昆谓便溺不通者，热秘之也。大螺性寒而善分清散，浊水之中，一着大螺，便能澄彻。剂之以盐，取其善润而已。[176p]

    In the "Examination of Medical Prescriptions," it is stated: In the late Song dynasty, there was a physician named Xiong Yancheng, aged fifty-five, who suffered from an illness causing him difficulty with urination and bowel movements. For five days, his abdomen was swollen like a drum, and his peers looked on, all unable to provide help. He was close friends with the monk Huiyue from West Lake and sent a message inviting him for a final farewell. The monk hurriedly went, encountering a strange guest at Da Qiao, who greeted him, saying, "Noble man from beyond the world, why do you hurry so?" The monk replied, "A good friend is suffering from a severe illness and is in critical condition; I wish to inquire about his health." The guest said, "It's an easy matter. Allow me to prepare a medicine." He then took off his shoes and waded into the water, retrieving a large conch shell. He said, "The matter is resolved." Upon returning home, he mixed half a spoon of salt with the conch shell, crushed it, and placed it an inch and three-fifths below the patient's navel, tightly binding it with a wide cloth, and also prepared a pot for urination to assist with his needs. The monk did not fully trust this approach and politely thanked him. When he arrived at Xiong's house, Yancheng was unconscious, and his wife and children were in tears. As other doctors had no other strategies, they cautiously tried this method. Without even taking a seat, the patient suddenly relieved himself. The doctors were ashamed and dispersed. The monk returned to inquire about the strange guest but could find no trace of him. Xiong lived for another sixteen years before passing away. The master stated that difficulty with urination and bowel movements is due to heat blockages. The conch shell has a cold nature and is good at dispersing and clarifying. In murky water, one touch of the conch can clear it. The salt is simply used for its moisture-retaining qualities.[176p]

    　　《寓意草》曰：姜宜人得奇证，简《本草经疏》治交肠用五苓散之说，以为神秘。余见之，辨曰：交肠一证，大小二便，易位而出，若交易然。古用五苓治之，专为通前阴而设也。若此证闭在后阴，二便俱从前阴而出，拟之交肠，诚有似是实非者。况交肠乃暴病，骤然而气乱于中。此证乃久病，以渐而血枯于内，有毫厘千里之不同，安得拟之？原夫疾之所始，始于忧思，结而伤脾。脾，统血者也。脾伤则不能统摄，而错出下行，有若崩漏，实名脱营。脱营病，宜大补急固。乃误认为崩漏，以凉血清火为治，则脱出转多。不思天癸已尽，潮汛已绝，万无是病。其年高气弱，无血以实漏　者，毫不念也。于是胞门子户之血，日渐消亡，势不得不借资而仰给矣。借资于大肠，转将大肠之血，运输而渗入胞囊。久之，大肠之血亦尽，而大肠之气附血而行者，孤而无主，为拳为块，奔腾涣散，与林木池鱼之殃祸同矣。[177p]

    The "寓意草" (Meaning of Herbs) states: Jiang Yiren obtained a strange testimony, referring to the explanation in the "Shen Nong's Classic of Materia Medica" regarding the treatment of intestinal disorders with the Wuling Decoction, deeming it mysterious. I observed this and clarified: the symptom of intestinal disorder involves both bowel movements, which can interchange as if they were trading. In ancient times, Wuling was used specifically to clear the front passage. If the symptoms are confined to the rear passage, with both bowel movements originating from the front, likening it to intestinal disorders indeed presents a chance of misunderstanding. Furthermore, intestinal disorders arise suddenly as a violent illness, causing chaotic qi within. This condition, in contrast, results from a chronic illness, where blood gradually depletes internally, showcasing a significant difference. How can they be compared?

    The root of illness begins with worry and grief, which can damage the spleen. The spleen regulates blood, and if it is damaged, it cannot control the flow, leading to erratic discharges similar to excessive bleeding or loss of vitality. In such cases, great supplementation and stabilization are necessary. However, if this is mistakenly treated as excessive bleeding, using methods to cool the blood and clear fire, the outflow will only increase. One fails to consider that with the end of the Tide of Life, there is no illness present. When one is aged and qi is weak, the absence of sufficient blood to control leads to neglect.

    As a result, the blood to the passages diminishes day by day, compelling the need to borrow resources from the large intestine, which in turn causes blood from the large intestine to seep into the reproductive organ. Over time, the blood from the large intestine also depletes, and its qi, which moves with the blood, becomes isolated and aimless, leading to chaos much like the calamities faced by the woods and waters.[177p]

    又如救荒者，剥邻国为立尽之墟所不顾矣。犹未也。仰给于胃脘，转将胃脘之血，吸引而渗入胞囊，久之胃脘之血亦尽，下脱之血，始无源自止。夫胃脘之血，所以荣周身而灌百脉者，今乃暗归乌有，则苞稂失润而委离足忧。血尽而止，较之血存而脱，又倍远矣。故血尽然后气乱，气乱然后水谷舍故趋新，舍宽趋隘。江汉两渠，并归一路，身中为之大乱，势必大肠之故道复通，乃可拨乱返治，与五苓一方，全无干涉。又况水谷繇胃入肠，另有幽门，泌别清浊，今以渗血之故，酿为谷道，是幽门辟为坦径矣，尚可用五苓再辟之乎？又况五苓之劫阴，为亡血家所深戒乎？今之见一病，辄有一药横于胸中，与夫执成方奉为灵秘者，大率皆误人者也。若宜人之病，余三指才下，便问曰：病中多哭泣否？婢媪曰：时时泣下。乃知脏燥者多泣，大肠方废而不用也，交肠云乎哉？今大肠之脉，累累而现于指，可虞之时，其来春枣叶生乎？枣叶生而言果验。
    [178p]

    Moreover, like those who save from disaster, they strip neighboring countries to establish a desolate place that they disregard. Yet it is still not enough. When the stomach area is nourished, the blood from the stomach area is drawn and seeps into the body’s cavities; after a long time, the blood of the stomach runs out, and the blood that is expelled has no source to stop it. The blood of the stomach is what nourishes the body and fills the meridians; now that it has become dark and returns to nothingness, the grass loses its moisture and the feet suffer worry. When the blood is exhausted and stops, it is far worse than when there is blood but it flows out. Thus, after the blood runs out, the qi becomes chaotic; when the qi is chaotic, the water and grains are neglected and therefore turn to new sources, neglecting spaciousness for narrowness. The channels of the Yangtze and Han rivers converge into one path, resulting in great chaos within the body. The large intestine must reopen its original pathway to restore order, and this has no relation to the prescription of Wuling. Furthermore, since the water and grains pass from the stomach to the intestines with a separate pylorus that distinguishes between the clear and the turbid, if due to the seepage of blood there arises a grain pathway, the pylorus becomes a smooth route. Is it still possible to reopen it with Wuling? Moreover, the affliction of Wuling is deeply cautioned against by those who worry about lost blood. Nowadays, seeing a single ailment, one often has a remedy obstructing the chest; as for those who uphold established prescriptions as spiritual secrets, most tend to mislead others. If one is to address someone’s ailment, I merely need to place three fingers lightly and then ask: “Are there frequent weeping episodes?” If a maid or elderly woman replies: “I weep often,” then it is known that dryness within the organs causes excessive weeping, and the large intestine is currently useless. What of the intestinal channels? Now, if the pulse of the large intestine is evident in the fingers, is it possible to predict when the spring jujube leaves will come? When the jujube leaves sprout, the fruits can be expected.[178p]
